(2) Are there any local government areas within the Sydney and Melbourne metropolitan areas that are not currently covered by a Migrant Resource Centre or Migrant Service Agency; if so, for each
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:such local government area what was the recorded number of (a) humanitarian stream arrivals and (b) family stream arrivals from English Proficiency group 3 and 4 countries in 2001-2002. (1) (a) The Migrant Resource Centre/Migrant Service Agency (MRC/MSA) service agreement identifies the level of core funding to be provided in respect of a specified work program and related outcomes and outputs. There is no breakdown of funding for salaries and ancillary costs and consequently it is not possible to relate funding to a number of funded staff positions. (b) Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS) funding is project based and funding is provided on the basis of the delivery of specified outcomes. Salaries are only one element of CSSS project costs, and it is not possible to identify the number of staff positions funded as part of these project costs. (2) There is full MRC/MSA coverage in Melbourne’s metropolitan local government areas. In metropolitan Sydney, the local government areas of Marrickville and Sutherland Shire do not fall within the catchment areas of any particular MRC/MSA. However, clients in these local government areas are serviced by organisations funded under the CSSS: Marrickville is serviced by the May Murray Neighbourhood Centre and Anglicare; and Sutherland Shire is serviced by the Gymea Community Aid and Information Service and through CSSS funding to St George MRC. The following table shows the numbers of Refugee and Humanitarian entrants and Family Stream migrants born in English Proficiency (EP) 3 and 4 countries settling in the local government areas of Marrickville and Sutherland Shire. The data in these tables was extracted from the Department’s Settlement Database1 on 11 February 2003. Local Government Area Refugee& Humanitarian Family EP3 & 4 counTotal arrivals for 2001-02 tries in 2001-02 Marrickville LGA 12 100 112 Sutherland Shire LGA 9 73 82 1 The Settlement Database is a dynamic database. Collection of some data is not mandatory at visa or arrival stage and may be added to the Settlement Database later on. Records are either added or updated daily. Updated statistical data is extracted on a weekly basis. As a result data provided for any stated period may change depending on when the statistical data was extracted. Marriage Celebrants: New Appointments (Question No. 1286) Ms Hall asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: (1) Has he proposed to increase the number of marriage celebrants by approximately 800 per year; if so, what impact will the increase have. (2) How will the increase impact upon the viability of marriage celebrants given that statistics issued by his Department indicate that in 2001 the number of weddings per 1000 head of population was at its lowest since 1901. (1) No. The Marriage Amendment Act 2002 (the Amendment Act) introduces the requirement that new marriage celebrants be trained, that all marriage celebrants undertake annual professional development and that their performance be regularly reviewed.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hardgrave
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:In order to reassure existing marriage celebrants that the market will not be flooded with new marriage celebrants the Amendment Act inserts a provision into the Marriage Act 1961 (section 39E) which caps the number of marriage celebrants who can be appointed each year for the first five years of the reformed program. As I stated in the Explanatory Memorandum, the cap will be 10% of the total number of marriage celebrants each year for the first five years. There are currently approximately 3,500 marriage celebrants appointed by the Commonwealth. Hence the maximum number that will be able to be appointed in the first year of the new system is approximately 350 (depending on the final number of current marriage celebrants at the time of the changeover to the new system). It is not possible for there to be 800 marriage celebrants per year appointed under the new marriage celebrant program at least for the first five years. The 10 per cent cap on appointments is just that – a cap. It is not a target that I am aiming to reach. Indications currently are that in some areas the cap may not be filled. This means that the number of new marriage celebrants is likely to be even less. As to the impact that any increase in the number of marriage celebrants will have on existing marriage celebrants, I believe that this will be gradual. The appointment of marriage celebrants under the new, open, transparent and competency based appointment criteria, together with the application of the cap, will give existing marriage celebrants time to adjust to a more market based environment. (2) I presume that the honourable member is, in fact, citing statistics issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics not my Department. Statistics issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics last year established that the crude marriage rate per head of population in 2001 was the lowest since these statistics were first recorded. I do not see the relevance of this to the viability of marriage celebrants. The marriage celebrants program is not about ‘dividing up’ marriages among marriage celebrants or ensuring that all marriage celebrants perform an equal number of marriages. The program, as reformed by the Amendment Act, is designed to ensure that all marrying couples enjoy high quality professional standards of service by marriage celebrants. The reforms are intended to raise standards. As I have noted, the cap on new appointments I have agreed to impose for the first five years will ensure that the increase in the number of new celebrants will be gradual. This will give current marriage celebrants time to adjust to the new system and its requirements. Telstra: Services (Question No. 1319) Mr Tanner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: (1) What revenue does Telstra derive annually from 190 numbers. (2) What revenue does Telstra derive annually from all international premium rate billing services. (3) Can Telstra provide a breakdown on the annual revenue derived from different categories of 190 numbers, including chat, friendship, sex, psychic and information numbers. (4) Does Telstra check 190 number service providers to ensure they are not providing services that are illegal; if so, what checks are made; if not, why not. (5) What checks does Telstra make on other premium rate billing services, including internet service providers, to ensure that the content such services are providing is not illegal. (6) Has Telstra considered terminating service agreements with 190 number providers, including Mediatel Services and Sound Advertising, who have had a large number of breaches against the Telephone Information Services Standards Council code of practice; if not, why not. (7) What steps does Telstra have in place to ensure that customers do not receive unexpectedly huge bills as a result of using 190 numbers and other premium rate billing services. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Telstra has advised that revenue information for 190 services is of a commercially confidential nature. (2) Telstra has advised that it does not provide any international premium rate billing services, and therefore does not derive any revenue from them. (3) No. See answer to part (1). (4) Telstra is required by Part 9A of Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999 to ensure that telephone sex services operate on the 1901 number range. Telstra must also ensure that consumers use a personal identification number (PIN), or other restricted access system to access the 1901 number range. Telstra has advised that it requires service providers issued with 190 numbers to comply with applicable legislation and the Telephone Information Services Standards Council (TISSC) Code of Practice in relation to telephone sex services. Telstra has advised that, in order to ensure that it complies with its legislative obligations in relation to the 1901 number range, it routinely checks the advertising of 190 services in the mass media to ensure no providers of telephone sex services are operating outside the 1901 number range. To date other premium rate services on the 190 number range are largely self-regulated, and Telstra advises that it refers questionable numbers to the relevant industry body, the Telecommunications Information Services Standards Council (TISSC). This industry body has a code of practice that deals with the supply and advertising of premium rate and Internet dialler services using 190 numbers. The TISSC Arbitrator, who investigates complaints about 190 services, has the power to direct a content service provider to refund a consumer’s payment, and even suspend or terminate a content service, where it finds that the provider has breached the code of practice. The Arbitrator may also refer complaints to Government agencies where it finds that there has been a breach of legislation that applies to premium rate services. (5) All domestic premium rate services are provided on the 190 number range. Telstra has advised it does not currently provide other premium rate billing services. Details on checks made by Telstra on its premium rate services on the 190 number range are provided in the answer to part 4. Telstra has advised that it has issued termination notices for existing Internet dialler services, effective on 25 August 2003. However, Telstra will consider limiting the scope of those notices to non-business content Internet diallers. This means that Telstra will consider new applications for business content Internet diallers and that business content Internet diallers may continue to be used. (6) Telstra has advised that it has previously disconnected a number of 190 services considered to be in breach of the TISSC code. Telstra has further advised that any information relating to specific contractual arrangement with individual service providers is a commercial in confidence matter. (7) Telstra has advised that it has controls in place to provide high usage warning reports that are used to alert customers to unusual 190 usage patterns in some circumstances. Telstra has advised that it has a number of phone management tools available to its customers. These include permanent barring of particular call types (eg 190, International, national long
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Artsdistance), which is free for Telstra customers, as well as a call control tool that can be switched on or off with a PIN for a monthly charge. Telstra Call Control is free for eligible pensioners. Telstra has also advised that, when customers take up a new Telstra service connection, they are advised of these safeguards and that they can avail themselves of these safeguards by calling Telstra. Customers wishing to access 1901 telephone sex services require a PIN to make all such calls; and can apply for a PIN to these services by calling Telstra. Additionally, for people calling premium services with charges of more than $4 per minute, calls are automatically disconnected after 30 minutes to reduce prolonged use of a 190 service. During each call, a tone is played every five minutes to alert customers to the passing time. The Government is introducing a range of regulatory measures, announced on 8 November 2002, to address consumer concerns about unexpected high bills for premium rate services (including 190 and international calls). Regulations, which came into effect on 4 December 2002, give the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) a broad range of flexible powers to regulate the supply of premium rate services. The Minister has now directed the ACA to: require carriers to bar access to premium rate services provided through 190 numbers where the total premium rate bill exceeds a specified monthly amount; ensure that telephone companies inform their customers about the risks associated with premium rate services, and the pre-emptive action they can take to protect themselves from unexpected high bills; and investigate as a matter of priority, and report back to the Minister by 31 July 2003 on the desirability of other measures that could be implemented, including: the barring of access to international numbers or number ranges; and specific requirements to be imposed in relation to Internet diallers; and the registration with the ACA of an industry code similar to thatcurrently operated by TISSC. Telecommunications: Phone Services (Question No. 1320) Mr Tanner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: (1) How confident is the Government that 1902 numbers advertising such things as “fantasy stories”, “anything goes” and “submissive ladies” are not telephone sex services. (2) Are telephone sex services meant to use the 1901 pin number system under Part 9A of the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999. (3) Further to the Minister’s media release entitled ‘Protecting Consumers from Internet Dumping’, dated 8 November 2002, at what stage are the Government and the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) at in implementing the package of measures to prevent unexpected high telephone bills and Internet dumping. (4) What progress has been made on each measure announced in the media release. (5) In regard to the ACA being directed to bar access to 190 premium service numbers once a premium rate bill exceeds a certain amount per month, has this measure been introduced and what is the prescribed amount; if the measure has not been introduced, why not and when will it be introduced. (6) Further to part (5), why did the Government choose to implement credit limits for 190 numbers only when consumers are also running up huge unexpected phone bills from overseas 0011 numbers. (7) Has the Government considered directing carriers to implement general optional credit limits on all consumer phone accounts for all billable services; if not, why not. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) It is not possible to determine whether a service is a “telephone sex service” within the meaning of Part 9A of the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999 (the T(CPSS) Act) merely from the way in which that service is promoted or advertised. The legislation requires that the content of the service must also be taken into account in answering this question. Where a complaint is made about a service, the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) may request that the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) investigate the service to determine whether it is in fact a telephone sex service. The ABA will examine the service in light of the factors outlined above and provide an evidentiary certificate, outlining whether, in the opinion of the ABA, the service is a telephone sex service. (2) Part 9A of the T(CPSS) Act requires that if charges for a telephone sex service appear on a telephone bill of a customer of a telephone service provider: the customer must have given consent in writing prior to the service being supplied; the customer must have been issued with a Personal Identification Number (PIN) or some other means of limiting access by others to the telephone sex service; the PIN or the other means of limiting access to the telephone sex service is to be used by the customer (or another end-user to whom the customer has divulged the PIN or other means of access) to access the service; and the service must have been supplied via a number with a ‘1901’ prefix . If charges for a telephone sex service are not to be included on a telephone bill, there is no requirement that the service provide a PIN or other access restriction, or operate on the 1901 number range. (3) The Government is introducing a range of regulatory measures, announced on 8 November 2002, to address consumer concerns regarding unexpected high bills for premium rate services and Internet dumping. Regulations, which came into effect on 4 December 2002, give the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) a broad range of flexible powers to regulate the supply of premium rate services. The Minister has also directed ACA to: (a) require carriers to bar access to premium rate services provided through 190 numbers where the total premium rate bill exceeds a specified amount per month; (b) ensure that telephone companies inform their customers about the risks associated with premium rate services, and the pre-emptive action they can take to protect themselves from unexpected high bills; and (c) investigate as a matter of priority and to report back to the Minister on the desirability of other measures that could be implemented, including: (i) the barring of access to international numbers or number ranges; (ii) specific requirements to be imposed in relation to Internet diallers; and (iii) the registration with the ACA of an industry code similar to that currently operated by the Telephone Information Services Standards Council (TISSC).
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the ArtsThe ACA has been directed to complete its investigations and report back by 31 July 2003. Service provider rules relating to a monthly call limit on calls to 190 numbers, and a consumer education campaign are to be made as soon as possible. (4) See answer to part (3). (5) As indicated in the answer to part (3) above, the ACA has been directed to impose a monthly call cap on 190 numbers. The ACA has not yet made the relevant service provider determination, as further investigations and stakeholder consultation are required. In determining an appropriate monthly limit, the ACA would be expected to have regard to industry compliance costs and consumer benefits. (6) and (7) The ACA has been directed to investigate and report on a range of initiatives that may address consumer concerns regarding unexpected high bills associated with premium rate services. It is open to the ACA to investigate credit limits for international numbers. The Government will consider the ACA report before deciding whether any further regulatory measures are necessary or appropriate. It should be noted, however, that measures already exist which allow consumers to protect themselves from unexpected high bills. Consumers who are concerned about unexpected high telephone bills can block access to premium rate services from their telephone. They can also install filtering software on their computers to block access to offensive material, including that accessed by Internet diallers. Taxation: Income Tax (Question No. 1331) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: What percentage of judges pay the top marginal rate of income tax. In preparing the response to this question the Australian Taxation Office utilised the occupation code used on tax returns to identify government appointed officials (occupation code 1103). This code covers coroners, judges and magistrates. Based on returns that have been lodged for the 2000-01 year the percentage of taxpayers using that occupation code who declared a taxable income in excess of $60,000 (the threshold where the top marginal rate of tax of 47% applies) is 83.9%. This is to be compared with 9.4% of the overall number of individuals who declared a taxable income in excess of $60,000. National Security: Hotline (Question No. 1333) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: (1) How many telephone calls have been received by the 1800 123 400 hotline for the “Lets look out for Australia” terrorism alert campaign. (2) What is the general nature of calls believed to be genuine. (3) How many calls have been found to be hoax calls. (4) How many calls have been acted upon and by whom. (5) What action has been taken by the various authorities in response to those calls believed to be genuine.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(6) Is the Government satisfied with the public response to its terrorism alert campaign; if so, why; if not, why not. (1) As at 28 February 2003, the National Security Hotline had taken 11,527 calls. (2) The majority of calls are genuine. These calls involved the provision of information about suspicious activity, the seeking of information about security arrangements and the threat environment, and comments regarding the campaign. (3) There have been three persons charged (one found guilty) for making a hoax or malicious call to the National Security Hotline. One related to an alleged bomb threat in Western Australia (found guilty), one related to an alleged threat, in New South Wales, against the Prime Minister and another related to an alleged extortion attempt in Victoria. (4) Commonwealth, State or Territory agencies analyse information received. All information relating to suspicious activities is forwarded to them by the Hotline for assessment. It is a matter for those agencies to determine the response to each call. (5) Agencies have advised that they are receiving useful information from the Hotline. Action taken is dependent on the nature of the information. (6) The fact that in excess of 11,500 calls have been received by the National Security Hotline since its inception is an indication of the success of the campaign. The majority of calls received by the Hotline relate to members of the public reporting, what is to them, suspicious activity. If only one of the calls prevents a terrorist attack, then the campaign will have served its purpose. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1336) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 1129, why did he believe that it was improbable that Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston would give his consent to exercise an exemption under the Privacy Act which would release the medical reports of the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston in May 1999 in relation to his fitness to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts. (2) Has he asked Dr Colston for his consent to the release of those two medical reports; if so when and what was Dr Colston’s reply; if not, why not. (3) Is he able to say whether the provisions of the Privacy Act to which he refers constitute a compellable power at law on him to exercise that power; if so, upon what basis is that compellableduty based; if not, why is the statutory power under the Privacy Act to seek the exemption from Dr Colston to consent to the disclosure of the subject information a non-compellable duty. (4) Is the exercise of this power an administrative power held in the hands of himself; if not, what type of power is it. (5) What power does he rely upon to make a decision on a balance of probabilities to refuse to consider the exercise of the statutory power under the Privacy Act to seek the consent of Dr Colston to publicly release the two medical reports. (6) Does the discretionary power to seek the consent of Dr Colston rest with Dr Colston. (7) Will he exercise his power afforded under the Privacy Act; if so, when; if not, why not. (8) In his refusal to exercise his statutory power to seek the consent of Dr Colston to the release of the two medical reports is he able to say whether this could be a breach of power or an error of law; if so, how; if not, why not.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(9) What are the reasons that he believes that the public interest of twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts is outweighed by the privacy provisions protecting the disclosure of the two medical reports in relation to Dr Colston. (10) In forming his opinion in relation to the weight of balance between the two competing interests, has he exercised an administrative power or a judicial power in his decision not to release the subject information covered by parliamentary privilege; if so, what is that power; if not, why not. (1) to (7) As explained in the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1129, Information Privacy Principle 11 of the Privacy Act provides that, subject to certain exceptions, personal information should not be publicly disclosed. One of the exceptions is where the subject of the information has consented to disclosure. Under the Privacy Act, consent is simply a qualification to a prohibition on disclosure and the Act neither imposes a duty nor confers a power on me to seek Dr Colston’s consent. In this case I will not seek consent because it is improbable that Dr Colston would consent to publication. The medical reports contain very sensitive and personal health information and in general individuals do not consent to publication of personal information of that kind. In addition, as a general rule seeking consent is inappropriate if it might be misinterpreted by the subject of the information or others as indicating a belief on my part that there may be sufficient public interest in disclosure for me to consider making an exception to the Privacy Act general principle of non disclosure of personal information. As explained in the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1129, in my view the balance of the public interest in this case does not weigh in favour of public release of the reports. (8) It is not appropriate for me to give legal advice in answer to questions on notice. (9) In giving the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1129 that the balance of the public interest does not weigh in favour of public release of the reports, I balanced the relative weight of the competing public interests. Given that disclosure of the reports is not necessary to protect the public revenue or to enforce the law (as stated in response to Question on Notice No. 1573 of 29 May 2000), the public interest in the public having access to the information is not strong. On the other hand the public interest against disclosure is strong, as evidenced by the Privacy Act general principle of non disclosure of personal information and the fact that in general individuals do not consent to publication of personal health information. (10) It is not appropriate for me to give legal advice in answer to questions on notice. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1337) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: Further to paragraph 3 of his reply to question No. 1130 that the public interest is not established because something is of interest to the public but a higher standard of serious concern or benefit to the public is required rather than merely of individual interest, why is the matter of the public release of those two medical reports, bearing in mind their relationship to the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts originally brought against Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, something that is of insufficient concern or benefit to the public. As explained in the answer given in response to Question on Notice No. 1130, in arriving at a balance of public interest in a particular case, it is necessary to consider whether the public interest considerations in disclosing the information outweigh the public interest in government agencies protecting the privacy of sensitive personal information in their possession. In this instance the balance favours a de-

Aviation: Passenger Indemnities (Question No. 1348) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: Are passengers who travel with commercial airlines protected by legislation for their costs if the airlines become insolvent; if so, what percentage of those costs are protected. There is no specific legislation that broadly covers the indemnity of passengers for losses if commercial airline services (both domestic and international) fail. In the case of international non scheduled services, however, the Air Navigation Act 1920 as amended requires a charter operator seeking to operate a program of non-scheduled passenger services (charter services) to satisfy the Secretary of the Department of Transport and Regional Services, as part of the application: “that holders of tickets for the flight or any of the flights will be indemnified for any financial loss that may be caused by the failure of the charter operator: (a) to fulfil its obligations; or (b) if the application relates to a program of flights – to complete the program.” Prospect Electorate: Bankruptcies (Question No. 1351) Mrs Crosio asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: How many persons in the electoral division of Prospect have been declared bankrupt pursuant to the Bankruptcy Act in (a) 1996-97, (b) 1997-98, (c) 1998-99, (d) 1999-2000, (e) 2000-2001 and (f) 20012002. Based on post code information given by bankrupts on their Statement of Affairs, the total number of persons in the electoral division of Prospect declared bankrupt under the Bankruptcy Act 1966 in 20012002 was 346. The post codes used to obtain this information were 2145, 2148, 2164, 2165, 2166, 2171, 2176 and 2759. The post code information is related to the relevant Commonwealth electoral division and is based on data sourced from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Some post code areas may cross electoral boundaries, resulting in minor discrepancies in reporting against electorate divisions when the post codes used do not necessarily equate to the relevant electorate boundary. I am unable to provide suitable information for the years prior to 2001-2002 because prior to July 2001 post code data was not regularly collected and recorded by the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia (ITSA) which collects and maintains personal insolvency data. theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Attorney
theText: General, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:(2) Will the Government take legislative or other measures to address the apparently discriminatory treatment of employees after they reach the age of 70. (1) On9 January 2003, the Government released an Information Paper setting out in detail its proposals for age discrimination legislation. The proposals include exemptions for legitimate age criteria in the provision of superannuation. The superannuation exemptions proposed for the age discrimination legislation were developed in the course of extensive consultations with business and community organisations. There was broad agreement in consultations that issues arising from the age criteria in the Commonwealth superannuation regime were best addressed through the ongoing review and adaptation of the superannuation system, rather than through age discrimination legislation. State and Territory anti-discrimination laws provide exemptions for superannuation, which allow for the inherently age-based nature of the existing superannuation system. Commonwealth antidiscrimination laws, such as the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992, also provide exemptions for superannuation. Age-related criteria are central to the Government’s policies to promote better incomes in retirement through superannuation and the age pension, and to ensure that superannuation (which is concessionally taxed) is appropriately used for retirement purposes. Superannuation and related social security and taxation laws are finely balanced and constantly monitored. The Government continues to monitor the operation of the superannuation system to ensure that it meets the needs of an ageing population. (2) The contribution and compulsory cashing rules for superannuation are designed to reduce the risk that concessionally taxed benefits are used for estate planning and not genuine retirement income purposes. Within this framework, however, the Government is committed to ensuring that the superannuation system reflects the needs of the ageing Australian population. On1 July 2002, the Government implemented its 2001 election commitment to raise the maximum age limit for personal superannuation contributions from age 70 to 75. All superannuation fund members aged between 65 and 75 can now make personal contributions to superannuation if they are working at least 10 hours per week. As a consequence of this measure, the Government has also changed the compulsory cashing rules for those aged between 70 and 75. The benefits of these members must be compulsorily cashed if the member is working fewer than 10 hours per week. Previously, all members aged over 70 were required to work full-time (at least 30 hours per week) to avoid compulsory cashing. The 30-hour standard remains for people aged over 75. Iraq (Question No. 1374) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 February 2003: (1) Has the Australian Government made any contact with the Iraqi opposition groups. (2) Have Government representatives met with the Iraqi National Congress; if so, what was the nature and content of those discussions. (3) What is the Government’s evaluation of various components of the Iraqi opposition. (4) Does the Government believe the opposition groups will have a serious role in governing Iraq in the event of the current regime collapsing. (5) What, if any, discussions have been held with opposition groups with regard to the continuation of existing and future Australian commercial relations. (1) Yes. (2) No, but INC representatives attended the Tallil conference on 15 April, where Australia was represented. (3) The numerous Iraqi parties, both within Iraq and among Iraqi exiles, vary greatly in organisational capabilities, membership and influence. Following the liberation of Iraq, Australia supports the early transfer of authority for running Iraq from the interim post-conflict coalition administration to Iraqis as soon as practicable. Australia also supports the Iraqi people’s efforts to form a democratic and stable government. (4) This is for the Iraqi people to decide. (5) None. Immigration: Asylum Seekers (Question No. 1448) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 February 2003: (1) How many asylum seekers have been issued with a temporary protection visa (TPV) from October 1999 to present time. title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) As at 7 February 2003, 8,616 people had been granted a temporary protection visa, since its introduction in October 1999. (2) The recorded nationality of all TPVs granted to date is as follows: Afghanistan 3607 Albania8 Algeria9 Angola1 Bahrain2 Bulgaria1 Burma6 Burundi2 China1 China (PRC) 2 Congo5 Cote D’Ivoire1 Egypt7 Greece1 India2 Iran 408 Iraq 4138 Jordan5 Korea4 Kuwait 12 Kyrgyzstan 1 Lebanon3 Morocco1 Nigeria1 Pakistan 27 Palestine 97 Philippines 2 Russia4 Rwanda1 Saudi Arabia4 Sierra Leone2 Somalia 15 Sri Lanka 126 Stateless 38 Sudan2 Syria 24 Tunisia3 Turkey 33 Turkmenistan 1 Ukraine2 Vietnam1 Yemen2 Yugoslavia 2 Zaire2 The above data indicates TPV holders’ nationality, rather than the country of origin as requested. Data held by my Department in relation to nationality is more reliable than country of origin. The Refugees Convention requires consideration of claims against the country of nationality or, if the asylum seeker is stateless, their country of habitual residence. An applicant’s country of origin is not a relevant consideration when assessing a protection visa application, and is often not indicative of a person’s nationality or country of habitual residence. (3) (a)-(c) Figures for the location of TPV holders in Australia at any given time are not currently available in the form requested. In general, lawful temporary residents of Australia are not obliged to keep DIMIA informed of their whereabouts unless they are applying for a further visa. However, statutory requirements that TPV holders keep my Department informed of their address were introduced in September 2001. There is a significant number of TPVs granted prior to the introduction of this requirement and some 16% of all TPV holders have not lodged further visa applications. Where TPV holders have made further applications for a protection visa, they are obliged as visa applicants, to keep DIMIA informed of their current address. Anecdotal information indicates that many of these addresses are not assiduously updated by the applicant until their TPV approaches the 30 month point, at which stage applicants are expecting that active decision making on their further PV application might commence. Special Benefit statistics from Centrelink covering around one half of the group of TPV holders provide the most reliable indication of the distribution of TPV holders between States and Territories. NSW & ACT– 52% VIC – 25% QLD – 4% SA – 11% WA – 7% TAS – .05% NT .05%. (2) How many families with Family Tax Benefit debts in (a) 2000-2001 and (b) 2001-2002 had part or all of their tax return withheld to satisfy that debt. ing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) In 2000/2001, 4,785 customers in the electoral division of Bowman incurred an overpayment of Family Tax Benefit. Member for Paterson: Electorate Office Accommodation (Question No. 1455) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 12 February 2003: (1) Is there a current lease at William Street, Raymond Terrace for premises formerly occupied by the Member for Paterson; if so, (a) how long before the lease expires, (b) will the Minister’s Department continue to pay the rent until the lease expires and (c) what is the annual rent being paid by the Department. (2) Does the Member for Paterson currently occupy rooms at Sturgeon Street, Raymond Terrace; if so, (a) what is the length of the lease, (b) what is the DOFA member entitlement for an electorate office area (square metres), (c) what is the area (square metres) of the office in Sturgeon Street, (d) is this area (square metres) within the DOFA member entitlement; if not, why not, (e) what is the annual rental for the property and (f) what were the relocation costs. ourable member’s question: (1) Yes, at 46 William Street, Raymond Terrace (a) the lease expires on 29 February 2004 however the Department through United KFPW is in negotiations with the lessor to accept surrender of the lease or agreement to sub lease the premises (b) Yes, unless the lessor accepts the surrender of the lease. (c) Commercial-in-confidence. Any disclosure could prejudice the ability of the Commonwealth to sub-let the property at a rate that represents value for money for the Commonwealth. (2) Yes, at 35 Sturgeon Street, Raymond Terrace (a) the lease expires on 17 December 2007 with an early termination clause in the 5th year (b) There is no “DOFA member entitlement” which specifies the size of an electorate office. Electorate offices are provided under item 7, Part 1, Schedule1 of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990. (c) 185 square metres. (d) Not applicable, because there is no “DOFA member entitlement” which specifies the size of an electorate office. However, it should be noted that the size of the office for the Member for Patterson (185 square metres) is less than that of the office of the Member for Hunter (200 square metres). (e) $58,275 per annum (f) $4,579 for removalists. title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toThe following table shows the total number of Medicare services provided during (a) 2001-2002 and (b) the six months to December 2002 in (i) Tasmania, (ii) the electoral division of Bass and (iii) selected postcodes*: Financial Year Tasmania Bass Selected Postcodes* 2001-2002 4,868,396 1,143,069 1,152,149 Jul-Dec 2002 2,512,804 611,293 616,078 * Selected postcodes are: 7248, 7249, 7250, 7252, 7253, 7254, 7255, 7257, 7258, 7259, 7260, 7261, 7262, 7263, 7264, 7265, 7267, 7268, 7277 and 7212. The statistics relate to services rendered on a ‘fee-for-service’ basis for which Medicare benefits were paid in the periods in question (based on date of processing). Excluded are details of services to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veterans’ Affairs patients and some compensation cases. The statistics in question were based on data captured at the servicing provider postcode level. In compiling statistics for the electoral division of Bass, since some postcodes overlap Federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate using data from the Census of Population and Housing showing the proportion of the population of each postcode in each Federal electoral division. The electoral division of Bass comprises the nominated selected postcodes. As some of these postcodes overlap other Federal electoral divisions, the statistics for Bass are a subset of those for the selected postcodes. Newcastle Electorate: Program Funding (Question No. 1482) Ms Grierson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: (1) Does the Ministers Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Ministers Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002. (5) What sum of Commonwealth funding did each recipient receive in 2001 and 2002. (6) What is the name and address of each recipient. title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:The Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS) also provides significant funding to Local Councils that benefit community organisations, businesses and individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle. In 2001-02 DOTARS provided Lake Macquarie City Council with $10,800,016 and Newcastle City Council with $9,704,844 under the Financial Assistance Grants to Local Government scheme. Newcastle City Council also received $300,000 under the Federal Black Spot Programme and was approved for funding of $2,996,619 under the Roads to Recovery Programme. Lake Macquarie City Council also was approved for funding of $4,515,985 under the Roads to Recovery Programme. (2) (a) Newcastle Structural Adjustment Programme Promoted on the DoTARS Web site: http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/adjustment/index.htm and funding rounds are advertised in relevant newspapers, local advisory committees and stakeholders are consulted as part of this process. The Newcastle Structural Adjustment Fund web site: http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/adjustment/newcastle/index.htm Road Safety Research Grants Road Safety Research Grants are advertised nationally in the Financial Review and the Weekend Australian. Information about these Grants, including application forms and guidelines for applicants, was published on the Internet at the Australian Transport Safety Bureau web site: http://www.atsb.gov.au/road/res-grnt/info.cfm Regional Assistance Programme The Regional Assistance Programme is promoted through the Area Consultative Committee (ACC) network. In consultation with their communities ACCs help identify local opportunities, priorities and development strategies for their regions. ACC’s use various media outlets to inform communities about accessing RAP funding. The RAP is promoted through the DOTARS regional web site http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/rap/index.htm and the ACC web sites: http://www.acc.gov.au as well as the Commonwealth Regional Information Service: http://www.regionalaustralia.gov.au/index.cfm and Grantslink: http://www.grantslink.gov.au Dairy Regional Assistance Programme The Dairy Regional Assistance Programme is promoted through Departmental Web sites: http://www.dotars.gov.au/regional/drap/index.htm, Grantslink: http://www.grantslink.gov.au . Area Consultative Committees promote the Programme on behalf of the Department through Dairy Regional Assistance Programme facilitators. Regional Solutions Programme The Regional Solutions Programme is advertised in national newspapers and electronically on the DoTARS web site: http://www.dotars.gov.au and http://www.regionalsolutions.gov.au as well as through the Commonwealth Government grants web site: http://www.grantslink.gov.au. The programme is also promoted through the Commonwealth Regional Information Service. (b) Where DOTARS advertises in print media such as local and national newspapers, the advertisements are paid for. (3) (a) Newcastle Structural Adjustment Programme In 1997 the Prime Minister established the Newcastle Structural Adjustment Fund (NSAF) following the announcement of the closure of the BHP Steel Division. To assist the local economy to adjust to the job losses, the Federal Government allocated $10 million for initiatives that would generate sustainable private sector employment growth within the Hunter Region. Road Safety Research Grants These grants are offered as a means to: promote innovative worthwhile research into road safety; and broaden the base of effective road safety researchers by encouraging established scientists, recent postgraduates, and commercial and community-based organisations to undertake research in the road safety field. Applications are invited from Australasian academic research institutions and Australasian commercial or community-based organisations. The research can be into any aspect of road safety. The maximum duration of a project is twelve months, and the maximum grant available is $25,000. Regional Assistance Programme The Regional Assistance Programme generates employment in metropolitan, regional and remote Australia by encouraging local community action to boost business growth and create sustainable jobs. It provides seed funding for innovative, quality projects of value to the community. Dairy Regional Assistance Programme Dairy RAP is designed to assist communities that have been impacted upon by the deregulation of the dairy industry. The programme facilitates long-term employment by supplementing business investment and provides support for services that will lead to on-going economic and social benefits for regions affected by dairy deregulation. Regional Solutions Programme Regional Solutions Programme is aimed at helping regional, rural and remote communities to build their capacity and to identify and implement development opportunities. It helps communities to move beyond planning by providing assistance to implement community initiatives, including community infrastructure. (b) Newcastle Structural Adjustment Programme The Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government allocates funds. Road Safety Research Grants Applications are assessed by an expert panel drawn from the Australian Transport Safety Bureau. Where appropriate, the selection committee seeks input from experts in other areas of the Department or from experts in the particular field of research to which the application relates. Regional Assistance Programme Final decisions on all applications are made by the Assistant Secretary, Stronger Regions Branch, Department of Transport and Regional Services. Dairy Regional Assistance Programme The Department of Transport and Regional Services is responsible for the allocation of funds. Regional Solutions Programme Final decisions on all applications are made by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. (2) Does the Ministers Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002. (5) What sum of Commonwealth funding did each recipient receive in 2001 and 2002. (6) What is the name and address of each recipient. (1) The Department of the Treasury does not administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle can directly apply for funding. All administered Commonwealth funded programs from the Department of the Treasury are provided directly to state governments. (2) N/a (3) N/a

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) N/a (5) N/a (6) N/a. Newcastle Eelctorate: Program Funding (Question No. 1489) Ms Grierson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002. (5) What sum of Commonwealth funding did each recipient receive in 2001 and 2002. (6) What is the name and address of each recipient. (1) The Department does not collect data by electorate. The addresses and postcodes of organisations receiving funding have been used to identify the funding provided to the electorate of Newcastle. The programs administered by the Department for which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding are: the Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP) the Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS); the Immigration Advice and Application Assistance Scheme (IAAAS); the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS); the Living in Harmony (LIH) Community Grants; and the Migrant Resource Centre (MRC) and Migrant Service Agency (MSA) network. IAAAS community services are delivered by contracted service providers at a State/Territory level. However, as IAAAS allocates funding to a service provider in the Newcastle area, funding amounts for this region have been included. (2) The Department advertises funding opportunities for all programs identified in (1) above other than MRC/MSA core funding. The following table provides details of how the Department advertises each program: Program (a) Medium of Advertising for funding (b) Are the advertisements paid by the Department? Yes/No AMEP The Australian newspaper. Yes CSSS Major metropolitan newspapers as well as selected Yes Rural, Regional, and Ethnic press. IHSS All national and major state/territory newspapers. Yes

(1) The Medical Rural Bonded (MRB) Scholarship Scheme (2a) The MRB Scholarship Scheme is advertised through: the Department of Health and Ageing’s web site, www.health.gov.au/workforce; distribution of flyers to medical school applicants who sit the Undergraduate Medicine and Health Sciences Admissions Test (UMAT) or Graduate Australian Medical Schools Admission Test (GAMSAT); distribution of flyers and information packs to medical school applicants by medical schools; and information on the Scheme is placed in most medical school prospectuses. (2b) The advertisements are not paid advertisements. (3a) The purpose of the MRB Scholarship Scheme is to address the workforce shortage of medical practitioners in rural and remote areas of Australia, and provides over $20,000 per year, indexed annually and currently tax free, to the scholarship recipients during the course of their medical degree. In return, scholars agree to work for six years in a rural or remote area once they have qualified and attained either a general practice or specialist Fellowship. (3b) The funds for the MRB Scholarships are allocated through the Department of Health and Ageing. Each University is responsible for the offering of the Scholarship and the tied MRB place to individuals as part of its medical school selection process. Funding allocation is through the State and Territory offices of the Department of Health and Ageing. The purpose of the Better Outcomes in Mental Health Care InitiativeAccess to Allied Health Services is to enable GPs to access psychological and other allied health services to support their patients with mental health disorders. Organisations may also be advised through various networks such as the Divisions of General Practice and the New South Wales Mental Health Service Suicide Prevention coordinators. (2b) Yes (3a) The objectives of the National Suicide Prevention Strategy are to: reduce deaths by suicide across all age groups in the Australian population, and reduce suicidal thinking, suicidal behaviour, and the injury and self-harm that result; enhance resilience and resourcefulness, respect, interconnectedness and mental health in young people, families and communities, and reduce the prevalence of risk factors for suicide; increase support available to individuals, families and communities affected by suicide or suicidal behaviours; and provide a whole of community approach to suicide prevention and to extend and enhance public understanding of suicide and its causes. (3b) The Central Office of the Department of Health and Ageing allocates funds on a State by State basis. State and Territory offices of the Department then conduct an open tender process to decide which organisations should be recommended for funding. The National Advisory Council on Suicide Prevention (NACSP) reviews State recommendations, and may endorse them or seek clarification. Only proposals endorsed by the NACSP are recommended for funding to the Minister. (1) Community Aged Care Packages (2a) New allocations of Community Aged Care Packages (CACPs) are advertised as part of the Aged Care Approvals Round (ACAR). The ACAR is advertised through the print media in both major metropolitan newspapers and regional daily newspapers, including the Newcastle Herald. Notification of the ACAR is also distributed via fax to existing Approved Providers and media releases are posted nationally. (2b) Yes (3a) CACPs are individually planned and coordinated packages of services, designed to meet older people’s daily care needs in the community. CACPs are a community alternative to low level residential care and are targeted at frail older people living in the community who require management of services because of their complex care needs. (3b) Aged Care Planning Advisory Committees (ACPACs) have responsibility under the Act for advising on the distribution of CACPs within each State and Territory. (4a) Planning for CACPs is done on an Aged Care Planning region basis not by individual electorates. Newcastle Electorate: Program Funding (Question No. 1498) Ms Grierson asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002. (5) What sum of Commonwealth funding did each recipient receive in 2001 and 2002. (6) What is the name and address of each recipient. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes, the programs are: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program; Veteran& Community Grants; Saluting Their Service Commemorations program; and Grants-in-Aid. (2) (a) and (b) The details of promoting the BEST, Veteran& Community Grants and Saluting Their Service Commemorations programs are shown below. No advertising is undertaken with the Grants-in-Aid program but the application form is available on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program The Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the website. Annual forums are held by Department of Veterans’ Affairs State Deputy Commissioners with various peak ex-service organisation representatives to address BEST funding for the coming financial year. From these forums, peak ex-service organisation representatives advise their members of funding arrangements. The Training Information Program (TIP). Information on the BEST program is incorporated into some TIP training sessions held in the States. A letter mail out advising of forthcoming BEST application periods. The mail out is circulated to existing grantees notifying them of forthcoming BEST funding. There are no paid advertisements for this program. Veteran& Community Grants The Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the website. The Grantslink website. A Commonwealth government grants website which is managed by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. The Department of Veterans’ Affairs State Office staff, Veterans’ Affairs Network (VAN) Office staff and Community Advisers. Information about Veteran& Community Grants are disseminated at this level through local visits, forums (such as ex-service organisation grant workshops), mail outs and newsletter articles directed at ex-service and targeted community organisations. There are no paid advertisements for this program. Saluting Their Service Commemorations Program The Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the website. The Grantslink website. A Commonwealth government grants website which is managed by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. A mail out to all Federal Members and Senators. Brochures are available from offices of the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. The only paid advertisement for this program is in the Australian Local Government Yearbook (2002). (3) (a) The purpose of each of the programs is: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program – The aim of this program is to provide support and resources to ex-service organisation practitioners for pension and welfare work to assist veterans and widow(er)s. Veteran& Community Grants– These grants aim to maintain and improve the independence and quality of life of members of the veteran community. The grants provide funding for projects which promote healthier lifestyles and enhance health, support carers, reduce social isolation and assist veterans and war widow(er)s to remain in their own homes as long as possible. Projects may also generate benefits for the wider community. Organisations that can demonstrate a contribution to the welfare of members of the veteran community are eligible to apply for funding. Saluting Their Service Commemorations Program– This program honours the contribution of Australia’s servicemen and women in wars, conflicts and peace operations. Grants may be approved under the program for the restoration, preservation and upgrading of community war memorials or, where no memorial exists in the town or suburb, the construction of a new memorial; the restoration, preservation and interpretation of Australian wartime memorabilia for public display; commemoration of significant anniversaries of battles and other military operations; significant reunions of units and school initiatives, eg research projects involving local veterans. The maximum generally available is $4,000. Grants-in-Aid– The aim of this program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that they provide to the ex-service community. (b) The Minister for Veterans’ Affairs. (5) (a), (b) and (c) To be assessed for VHC services a person must be: a veteran of the Australian defence forces; or an Australian mariner; or a war widow/widower of a veteran of the Australian defence forces or an Australian mariner; and have a Repatriation Health Card For All Conditions (Gold Card); or a Repatriation Health Card For Specific Conditions (White Card). To be provided with services a veteran must have a demonstrated need. The Assessment Agency conducts the initial assessment over the phone using the VHC assessment instrument. Triggers are built into the assessment instrument indicating when an in-home assessment is required, for example circumstances where the veteran has a hearing loss, or cognitive impairment. Data is entered directly into the VHC IT system and if services are approved a service plan is sent to the nominated service provider and a care plan to the veteran. (6) (a), (b) and (c) Veterans’ Home Care No, veterans residing in aged care facilities, funded by the Department of Health and Ageing, are not eligible to receive Veterans’ Home Care services. This accommodation is already receiving government funding under the Aged Care Act 1997, which is set at a level to meet residents’ needs. Rehabilitation Appliances Program Access to the provision of equipment under the RAP to entitled persons is based upon an assessed clinical need(s) and is governed by the Treatment Principles, prepared under Section 90 of the Veterans’ Entitlements Act 1986. The assessment of an entitled person’s clinical need/s is conducted by specified health professionals, usually an occupational therapist, upon referral from, and in consultation with, the entitled person’s Local Medical Officer (LMO). The guidelines governing the supply of RAP items to entitled persons residing in institutions (including low level hostels) is specified under Treatment Principle 11.3.6. In genral, it is the responsibility of the Residential Aged Care Facility (RACF) to cater for the needs of its residents. However, if the Repatriation Commission considers the equipment requested by the entitled person receiving low-level care or high level care is not the responsibility of the RACF because of any legislation, charges or subsidies, then the Commission may consider the request based on assessed clinical need and in accordance with the national guidelines. These guidelines apply regardless of whether the person making the request is in an institution or not and relate to the item requested. Taxation: Avoidance Schemes (Question No. 1501) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: (1) Did the Taxation Commissioner, Mr Michael Carmody issue a warning on 11 February 2003 to small business owners in relation to those individuals who participate in tax avoidance schemes by using fixed trusts to distribute profits into self-managed superannuation funds and thereby expect to receive the 15% concessional rate of tax. (2) Is the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) investigating those schemes; if so, what is the outcome of the ATO’s investigation; if not, why not. (3) Is he aware whether any (a) barristers or (b) solicitors are (i) personally participating in or (ii) promoting these schemes to their clients; if so, how many barristers and solicitors have been identified. (1) The Commissioner of Taxation issued a Taxpayer Alert on 11 February 2003 to provide an early warning to taxpayers of the issues arising from a scheme that uses an interposed fixed trust to distribute profits into a self managed superannuation fund. (2) Taxpayer Alerts are designed to provide an early warning to taxpayers of arrangements that the ATO is investigating. Investigations are not yet complete. (3) One of the benefits of issuing early warnings is that potential participants are aware of the ATO’s concerns before deciding whether or not to enter into an arrangement or claim the tax benefit. The Commissioner of Taxation is continuing his investigations but at this early stage he advises promotion of this arrangement was not aimed at solicitors and barristers and there does not appear to be any significant participation by these groups. Health: MRI Machines (Question No. 1503) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: (1) Further to part (5) of the answer to question No. 358 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, page 4941) and part (7) of the answer to question No. 884 (Hansard, 22 October 2002, page 8391), has the Minister seen a News Release by the NSW Minister for Health on 11 February 2003, titled “MRI at Concord Hospital” advising that the Carr Labor Government has already promised to fund the significant building works required and the ongoing operating costs for a new Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) unit at Concord Repatriation General Hospital, but that the NSW Minister first needs the licence from the Federal Government. (2) When will the Minister offer Concord Repatriation General Hospital an MRI licence and allow it to provide Medicare eligible MRI services. the honourable member’s question: (1) I have not seen the news release by the NSW Minister for Health titled “MRI at Concord Hospital”. Staff in my Department have searched extensively for this news release and have not been able to locate it. In fact, staff at the NSW Health Minister’s own office are unaware of it. With regard to the NSW Health Minister’s need for a federal licence, whilst the Commonwealth Government regulates the conditions under which MRI services attract Medicare rebates it does not regulate or restrict the establishment of MRI units in public hospitals. As such, there is no

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toimpediment to the New South Wales State Government funding the establishment of a MRI unit at the Concord Repatriation General Hospital. I would welcome the New South Wales Government’s commitment to the provision of quality health care were it to do so. (2) The Government has not made any decisions on future growth for MRI and I am therefore unable to indicate whether Concord Hospital would obtain Medicare eligibility for a MRI unit. In addition, the Department of Health and Ageing is currently negotiating with the Diagnostic Imaging (DI) profession on future DI agreements. Future priorities for MRI and other DI services will need to be considered in the context of these negotiations. It is also worth noting that Medicare funded access to MRI in metropolitan Sydney is above the national average. Shipping: Navigation Act Review (Question No. 1510) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: Has a review been undertaken of the Navigation Act; if so, (a) who conducted the review, (b) was a report produced, (c) when will it be available to the public, (d) what did the review recommend, (e) what is the status of the recommendations, (f) when will the industry be consulted and (g) when will they be implemented. The Government decided on 16 December 1997 to review the Act in two stages. The first stage considered repeal of matters that impede shipping reform or are inconsistent with the concept of company employment. This review stage was completed in 1998 and resulted in the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998, which was introduced into Parliament on 25 June 1998. The House of Representatives passed the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 but it was obstructed in the Senate. The second stage focussed on the remaining parts of the legislation that restricts competition or trading opportunities, are anachronistic or redundant, or which impose costs or confer benefits on business. The report of the second stage, entitled Review of the Navigation Act 1912, was released in June 2000 and has been available on the Department of Transport and Regional Services website at http://www.dotars.gov.au/transinfra/navact_reference.htm. The report is the most recent review of the Navigation Act and provides much of the information sought including the timing and conduct of the review, industry consultation and recommendations. The implementation of the recommendations is being considered in the context of the Government’s legislative program, bearing in mind the experience of earlier attempts to amend aspects of the Navigation Act 1912 that would have modernised and simplified the regulatory framework for ship operations. In addition to the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 referred to above, the Maritime Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 which sought to revise the trading ship safety regulatory framework under the Navigation Act 1912 was also passed by the House of Representatives but obstructed in the Senate. title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) (a) The Department does not undertake aged care planning on an electorate basis; it is undertaken on the basis of Aged Care Planning Regions. These regions do not coincide with the Federal electorates. The following table identifies CACP packages allocated to the planning regions which cover the electorates in question. Metro South West 567 Metro North 504 Metro East 356 Metro South East 297 South West 186 Wheatbelt 55 Goldfields 52 Kimberley 50 Pilbara 56 Mid West 37 Great Southern 28 (b) There are two EACH providers in Western Australia, who provide a total of 75 EACH packages in Perth. Their combined client catchment areas include suburbs within the electorates of Swan, Canning, Hasluck, Tangney, Curtin, Perth, Stirling and Cowan. (3) A total of 202 CACP’s have been allocated to providers based in these postcode areas. No Extended Aged Care at Home packages have been allocated to providers based in these postcode areas. (4) Extended Aged Care at Home packages can provide complex nursing care. Packages of care may also include continence aids, oxygen, oxygen equipment and access to hoists and higher levels of personal care than Community Aged Care Packages. (5) EACH packages are funded at the level of residential care subsidy level 2. There is no direct saving to Government compared to residential care. (6) EACH is a small program in its developmental stage. Services are available in the following planning regions: State Planning Regions Number of places NSW South West Sydney 28 North Sydney 18 Illawarra 20 ACT ACT 30 SA Metropolitan East 35 VIC Western Metropolitan 15 Grampians 35 Loddon Mallee 34 TAS North-Western 13 Southern 12 NT Darwin 20 WA Metropolitan North 50 Metropolitan South 25 (7) People who live in suburbs with no access to Extended Aged Care at Home packages may access Community Aged Care Packages (CACP’s) and Home and Community Care (HACC) services. The HACC Program aims to provide a comprehensive, coordinated and integrated range of basic maintenance and support services for frail aged people, people with a disability and their carers. HACC services include community nursing, personal care, meals, domestic assistance, home modification and maintenance, transport and community based respite care. The HACC Program is a joint Commonwealth, State and Territory funded initiative, where the Commonwealth contributes 60% of the funding. In 2002-03, the Commonwealth will contribute $674.1 million for HACC services. Immigration: Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (Question No. 1521) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) What household items are provided to eligible humanitarian entrants under the Household Formation Support (HFS) element of the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS). (2) Are items such as lounge furniture, wardrobes and chests of drawers excluded from the list of approved items; if so, is it assumed that charities will provide humanitarian entrants with such items out of their own resources. (3) Are contracted service providers funded a set sum per household to provide approved household items; if so, what is this sum and on what basis was it determined. (4) Have HFS service providers expressed concern about their capacity to provide adequate HFS assistance to clients within the current financial constraints of the scheme; if so, what has been the response of his Department. (1) Eligible humanitarian entrant families under the HFS element of IHSS receive a basic set of household goods depending on family needs. The following items are included: Mattresses Table Chairs Refrigerator Pillows Bedding (sheets and blankets) A quantity of crockery and cutlery appropriate to the household size including cooking utensils and saucepans. (2) There is no restriction on supplementing the basic package of goods with other items, such as lounge furniture, wardrobes and chests of drawers but this is largely dependent on the availability of donated goods. (3) Yes, HFS service providers are funded a set sum per family to provide household items, which is indexed annually for CPI increases. In 2002-03 this amount is $1200 per family. It was based on providing a basic set of goods for an average family size of 3.5 persons. The intent of HFS is that service providers have flexibility within the available funds to tailor a package for a family, and it is open to service providers to adjust the amounts provided to individual families although in practice needs are such that most receive the standard package. (4) Yes, HFS service providers have expressed concerns regarding the limited amount of funding in the context of the IHSS Evaluation and in comments to the Review of Settlement Services. A response will be considered in the light of the Report on the Settlement Services Review.
