Telstra: Services (Question No. 1536) Ms Corcoran asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) Was there a failure of telecommunications services in Omeo on Saturday, 25 January 2003.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Are telecommunications to Omeo provided through two switching centres at Wangaratta and Morwell. (3) Was there an optic fibre failure from Wangaratta and a mains power failure to Morwell and the Morwell telephone exchange which led to the isolation of Omeo and surrounding areas. (4) Was backup power provided at the Morwell exchange through local power generation equipment, and was the capacity of the equipment adequate to cover the mains power failure. (5) What arrangements have been put in place to prevent such a serious failure happening again. (6) Was the telecommunications failure at Morwell similar to previous mains power cuts at Pakenham and Kyneton telephone exchanges which also led to major telecommunications outages. (7) What arrangements are in place to monitor such failures. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question based on information provided by Telstra: (1) Yes. A telephone exchange failure affected fixed services connected to the Omeo Telephone Exchange for a period of 102 minutes Telstra CDMA mobile phone services at Omeo were not affected by this outage. This Outage was as a result of two isolated and unusually rare coincidental elements. On the 25th of Jan 2003 at 4:47pm a transmission failure occurred between Bright and Hotham Heights. This was caused by the underground optical fibre cable between Bright and Mt Hotham being damaged by fire emergency services crews constructing a fire break for the bush fires in that area. This outage had no effect on telephone services in Omeo at this time. The Mt Hotham area was declared an unsafe and hazardous area and Telstra staff were delayed for several days in entering the area to repair the damaged optical fibre cable. On Saturday the 25th of January a grass fire at Morwell caused a general mains power failure which resulted in loss of mains power to the Morwell telephone exchange. The Morwell exchange’s emergency power generator would normally have started to operate. However, the generator failed due to overload when both the exchange rectifiers and the air conditioning unit attempted to start up at the same time. The loss of transmission to Omeo was caused by the subsequent air conditioning unit failure at Morwell. (2) Yes, communications to Omeo are protected by two transmission paths; Morwell to Omeo via Wangaratta and Mt Hotham, and Morwell to Omeo via Bairnsdale. With the damage to the optical fibre cable caused by the bushfires at Mount Hotham, Omeo still had service via a backup transmission path to the telephone switch at Morwell via Bairnsdale. However, the backup transmission path was lost when the air conditioning unit at Morwell subsequently failed. If not for the day’s earlier fire damage and the compounding effects of the Morwell air conditioning failure, service would have remained uninterrupted to Omeo because traffic would have been able to travel along one of two routes: Morwell to Omeo via Wangaratta and Mt Hotham, and Morwell to Omeo via Bairnsdale. (3) Yes, there was optic fibre failure resulting in fixed line services through Omeo being affected. However, Telstra’s CDMA mobile phone service allowed mobile communications to the Omeo area to continue during the outage. (4) Under normal circumstances, the emergency power plant at Morwell is adequate for the purpose. However, the extreme weather conditions on the 25th January (some 45 Degrees Celcius) meant that when the generator at the Morwell exchange started up, the load on it from the rectifiers and the air conditioning unit at start-up was too great, resulting in the failure of the generator and the air conditioning unit.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(5) The cutting of the optical fibre cable at Mt Hotham was beyond the control of Telstra. Telstra has already modified power equipment and the air conditioning unit at the Morwell exchange to ensure that the power overload condition does not arise in the future. (6) No. All failures were based on different causes. (7) The Telstra Global Operations Centre continuously monitors Telstra’s network, immediately following up any network and/or power alarms. Additionally, routine maintenance programs and load testing are undertaken on all mains power back-up systems. Such testing is undertaken under normal load conditions -it is extremely difficult to simulate the heat conditions experienced on the 25th January. Immigration: Visa Cancellations (Question No. 1537) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) Since the Government’s election in 1996 to the present day, how many visas has he personally cancelled. (2) Will he provide a time line for cancellations. (3) In each case, what type of visa was held. (4) On what grounds was each visa cancelled. (5) Why were the visas cancelled by him rather than a delegate, thus ruling out any right of administrative review. (6) What are the guidelines for the cancellation of a visa by the Minister, as opposed to a delegate. (7) Can he provide details of any changes since the introduction of the scheme for visa cancellation on character grounds centred on s.501 of the Migration Act in relation to (a) the proportion of cancellation decisions made by the Minister personally, rather than by delegates and (b) the policies or guidelines applying to the question of whether and when such decisions are to be made by the Minister personally, rather than by delegates. (8) In relation to the introduction of any such changes, what consideration was given to the fact that a person whose visa is cancelled in this way by the Minister personally has no right of independent review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), whereas there is such a right of review when the decision is made by a delegate. (9) Was one of the reasons for the introduction of any such change a desire to remove the right of independent review in the AAT. (1) There are a number of powers in the Migration Act 1958 that I can utilise to cancel a visa. These are: section 109 incorrect information section 116 general power to cancel section 128 when holder outside Australia section 134 cancellation of business visas section 137Q cancellation of regional sponsored employment visas section 140 consequential cancellation of other visas section 500A refusal or cancellation of temporary safe haven visas section 501 refusal or cancellation of visa on character grounds
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:section 501A or 501B refusal or cancellation of visa – setting aside and substitution of nonadverse decision under subsection 501 (1) or (2) Since1 June 1999, section 501 has predominantly replaced criminal deportation as the method used to ensure the safety and welfare of the Australian community. Previously, section 200 had been used for this purpose. The vast majority of decisions made under these powers are decided by Department officers acting as my delegates. Decisions I have taken personally to cancel a visa are predominantly related to character concerns, often involving significant criminal activity. Based on the records available to the Department some 58,200 visas have been cancelled since 1996-97, of which I have personally cancelled approximately 570 visas. (2) The time line for any case where possible visa cancellation is to be considered can vary significantly depending on a range of elements relevant to the case in question. Such elements may include the particular circumstances of the case, whether further information may be required to reach a decision, including information from other agencies, where appropriate, submissions from the person concerned regarding the proposed cancellation and whether there are international obligations that need to be taken into account. These processes are an important step in ensuring that all relevant material pertaining to a decision, and my responsibility to protect the Australian community, are given proper consideration against the relevant legislation before a decision is made. (3) The Department does not keep statistics on the specific type of visa cancelled by me, although most would be permanent residents who had criminal records. (4) The Department does not keep statistical data on the “grounds” for section 501 cancellations in individual cases. The Migration Act sets out the possible grounds for cancellation decisions where the person does not pass the “character test”. (5) The Government is most concerned at the presence in Australia of non-citizens convicted of serious crimes and believes the Australian community is entitled to be protected against them. Generally, I decide cases personally under section 501 of the Migration Act if a visa holder (normally a permanent visa holder) is to be considered for cancellation as a result of serious character concerns regarding the visa holder. I may also set aside a non-adverse decision whether it has been considered by a delegate or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) under section 501A, if the person does not satisfy me that they pass the “character test” and I am satisfied the cancellation is in the national interest. (6) Guidelines to consider possible visa cancellation are provided to my delegates in Migration Serial Instructions (MSIs) 133, 254, 335 and 368. Direction No. 21 made under s499 of the Migration Act (“Visa refusal and cancellation under section 501”) provides further instruction for delegates. While I may be informed by these guidelines I have discretion to consider each case on its own merits. (7) (a) Visa cancellations on character grounds centred on s501 of the Migration Act predominantly replaced criminal deportation under s200 from 1 June 1999. The proportion of cancellation decisions made by the Minister personally is given in the table below: The proportion of cancellation decisions made by the Minister personally: Date Minister Total No. of Cancellations % by Minister 1996-97 4 2970 0.13% 1997-98 10 4828 0.20% 1998-99 40 6920 0.57% 1999-00 114 7808 1.46% 2000-01 133 8879 1.49% Date Minister Total No. of Cancellations % by Minister 2001-02 137 14614 0.93% 2002-March 2003 135 12220 1.10% (b) As I stated in my response to part (5), I generally decide cases personally under section 501 of the Migration Act if a visa holder (normally a permanent visa holder) is to be considered for cancellation as a result of serious character concerns. I may also set aside a non-adverse decision by a delegate or the AAT under section 501A if the person does not satisfy me that they pass the “character test” and I am satisfied that it is in the national interest to cancel that person’s visa. (8) and (9) The powers I have under s501 and s501A of the Migration Act were approved by Parliament. As I informed the Parliament in my Second Reading Speech for the Migration Legislation Amendment (Strengthening of Provisions relating to Character and Conduct) Bill 1998, these powers are used when it is necessary for me “to act decisively on matters of visa cancellation … to ensure that the government can effectively discharge its fundamental responsibility to prevent the entry and stay in Australia of non-citizens who have a criminal background or have criminal associations”. Rural and Regional Australia: Flood Mitigation Program (Question No. 1544) Mrs Irwin asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) Has the Federal Government provided funding for flood mitigation works in Fairfield City, NSW. (2) In what year was the funding discontinued. (3) For what reason was funding discontinued. (4) What sums does the government expend on the Regional Flood Mitigation Program. (5) Does the Regional Flood Mitigation Program allow for funding for works in outer metropolitan areas; if so, (a) what outer metropolitan areas have received funding under the program and (b) why is Fairfield City not included in the definition of outer metropolitan. (1) Yes. (2) 1996-1997. (3) The Federal Government ceased to provide assistance for urban flood mitigation funding in 19961997 in line with the recommendation of the 1996 National Commission of Audit Report. (4) Since the RFMP was established in 1999-2000, the Federal Government has allocated $30.35 million to flood mitigation works and measures across Australia. A further $9.6 million will be allocated nationally in both 2003-2004 and 2004-2005. (5) In May 2001, the RFMP was expanded to include outer metropolitan areas. The Federal Government has advised States and Territories that it is a matter for them, as part of their project assessment processes, to determine outer metropolitan boundaries. (a) The NSW Department of Land and Water Conservation has advised my Department that the following outer metropolitan areas have received RFMP funding: Wentworthville (Parramatta City Council); Baulkham Hills (Baulkham Hills Shire Council); Camden (Camden Council)
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(b) The inclusion or exclusion of Fairfield City under the RFMP is a matter for the NSW State Government. Royal Commission: Building and Construction Industry (Question No. 1546) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 2003: (1) Has he seen a copy of the Cole Royal Commission report into the building industry. (2) What action will he take against the directors of the so-called Phoenix companies in the building industry whom Commissioner Cole has (a) exposed for serially abandoning workers of their legitimate entitlements and (b) identified as engaging in the stripping of companies to avoid the payment of tax to the Australian Taxation Office, similar to the bottom-of-the-harbour operators of the 1960s and 1970s. The Government tabled the Royal Commission Report into the Building and Construction Industry on Wednesday, 26 March and Thursday, 27 March. The Government is currently considering the report and will provide a formal response in due course. Education: Aboriginal Tutorial Asistance Scheme (Question No. 1559) Ms Jann McFarlane asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 4 March 2003: (1) Is he aware of any schools being forced to suspend the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme until next financial year due to a lack of funding, if so, how many schools have been affected. (2) Can he confirm if any schools in the Stirling electorate have been notified by the Aboriginal Education Unit of the Department of Education, Science and Training that there is no more money to continue this vital program until the new financial year. (1) I am not aware of any schools in the Stirling electorate which have been forced to suspend the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme (ATAS). (2) Two schools in the Stirling electorate accessed the Tuition During School Hours (TDSH) element of ATAS during 2002. The TDSH element of ATAS is being maintained at the same level in 2003 as Semester Two, 2002 in Western Australia. Veterans: Vietnam (Question No. 1560) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 4 March 2003: (1) Who is eligible for inclusion in the Nominal Roll of Vietnam Veterans and what period does the Nominal Roll cover. (2) Are there any Australian Defence Force personnel who served in the Active War Zone of South Vietnam, not prior to, but after, the Paris Agreement was signed on 27 January 1973, included in the Nominal Roll. Defence: Special Operations Command (Question No. 1604) Mr Price asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 March 2003: (1) Further to his Press Release of 19 December 2002 announcing the formation of the Special Operations Command, will the full component of 310 highly trained soldiers referred to only be provided in 2006. (2) As soldiers are selected for the Special Operations Command, will the resultant vacancies be back filled or will the unit be left hollow. (3) How many positions will be involved in the Special Combat Service Team and when will it be fully operational.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the follow
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the follow(4) In relation to the Special Operations Command; for each rank, how many (a) existing positions and (b) new positions will be involved and over what time period will they be filled. (5) What additional equipment is required to have the Special Operations Command mature and fully functional and what is the cost. (6) As a result of his announcement, what additional funds have been provided to the Australian Defence Force for Special Operations Command. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) No. The Army will progressively transfer and recruit soldiers into Special Operations Command after its formal establishment on 1 May 2003. (2) Army will progressively fill all vacancies within the Special Operations Command from May 2003 to January 2006 and will back fill positions left vacant as soldiers transfer from conventional units to Special Operations Command. The Army is considering direct recruiting to Special Operations Command to reduce the impact on units outside Special Operations Command. (3) The Special Operations Combat Service Support Company is a sub-unit sized organisation. The specific numbers cannot be released for security reasons. The Special Operations Combat Service Support Company will be operational by 2006. (4) The detailed numbers and growth plan for the Special Operations Command are classified. It is expected that the Special Operations Command will grow from approximately 1800 to approximately 2500 all ranks by January 2006. These figures include the staff for the Headquarters and all the units of the Command. (5) Details of the equipment being provided to the additional Commando Company and to the new Combat Service Support Company cannot be released for security reasons. The cost of the equipment will be announced at the Budget. (6) The additional funds forecast for Special Operations Command over the next three financial years will be available at the time of the Budget. Health: Iophendylate (Question No. 1609) Mr Price asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 18 March 2003: (1) Over what period was the drug iophendylate, otherwise known as Pantopaque or Myodil, licensed for use in Australia. (2) When was the licence withdrawn or ceased and for what reason. (3) Does Myodil contain: (i) Benzene, (ii) Hydrochloric Acid, (iii) Sulphuric Acid, (iv) Potassium Permanganate, and (v) 30% Iodine. (4) Is it the case that (a) Benzene is regarded as a leading carcinogenic, (b) Potassium Permanganate can kill if digested, and (c) incorrect use of Iodine can lead to Parkinson’s disease. (5) Have the patients who were given Myodil been identified; if not, why not. (6) Have those same patients been advised by the Minister’s department, or any other Commonwealth agency, about the potentially adverse effects of Myodil; if not, why not. (7) How many patients who were prescribed iophendylate subsequently developed Adhesive Arachnoiditis. (8) Is there a known cure or treatment for Adhesive Arachnoiditis. (9) Have any studies been undertaken in Australia into the number of Adhesive Arachnoiditis sufferers; if so, what are the details. (10) Has the Minister’s Department, or any other Commonwealth agency, sponsored research into the after effects of the use of Myodil. (11) Has the Minister’s Department, or any other Commonwealth agency, provided financial support for Adhesive Arachnoiditis support groups. the honourable member’s question: (1) Myodil and Pantopaque imaging dyes were available in Australia from at least the early 1960s until the late 1980s. They were thus available before the introduction of Commonwealth regulation of medicines and therapeutic products in 1970. At the time of their use, they were the best method available to help diagnose serious spinal conditions, including disc diseases and tumours. No other form of contrast dye was available for myelography until the late 1970s. In the late 1970s, the Therapeutic Goods Administration’s predecessor, the Therapeutic Goods Branch of the then Department of Health, evaluated an application to register Pantopaque, for general marketing in Australia. This application was approved in October 1979. (2) Myodil and Pantopaque were removed from the market in the late 1980s by their sponsors due to a lack of demand, as newer diagnostic techniques, such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Computerised Topography (CT) scans, became available. (3) Like many drugs, iophendylate contains a benzene unit within its chemical structure, but does not contain the compound benzene itself. It does contain 30.5% of organically bound iodine, but this, again, is part of the molecule itself and free iodine is unlikely to be released. There is no evidence that Myodil contains hydrochloric acid, sulphuric acid or potassium permanganate. However, some of these chemicals may have been used during the manufacture of iophendylate. (4) (a) Yes, benzene is a known carcinogen; (b) potassium permanganate is harmful if swallowed; and (c) the Department can locate no scientific evidence indicating that incorrect use of iodine can lead to Parkinson’s disease. (5) No. At the time these dyes were first used, there was no Commonwealth regulation of therapeutic goods. Subsequently, regulation focussed on supply was introduced. As with any other product available on the market, the Commonwealth would not keep or have access to details of use in individual patients. (6) No, but these products could only be given on the prescription of a doctor. The prescribing information for health professionals for Myodil from the early 1970s, and for Pantopaque when it was granted marketing approval, stated that the product should be removed after the myelographic procedure, and warned about the possibility of arachnoiditis and other adverse effects. Information on possible adverse effects was also documented in the scientific literature. (7) It is not known how many sufferers of Adhesive Arachnoiditis are in Australia or what proportion of these had been treated with iophendylate prior to the development of this condition. However, it has variously been reported in the published scientific papers that clinically significant Arachnoiditis occurs in around 1% of patients who have undergone myelography with such dyes. (8) The Department is not aware of a known cure or treatment for Adhesive Arachnoiditis. (9) The Department is not aware of any Australian studies into the number of sufferers of Adhesive Arachnoiditis. (10) The Department of Health and Ageing has not sponsored research into the after effects of the use of Myodil. I cannot comment on whether other Commonwealth agencies have sponsored such research.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(11) The Department of Health and Ageing has not provided financial support for Adhesive Arachnoiditis support groups. I cannot comment on whether other Commonwealth agencies have provided financial support. Aviation: Air Safety (Question No. 1617) Mr Bevis asked the Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 18 March 2003: What safety restrictions apply to the number of hours that: (a) pilots, and (b) air crew are able to work on domestic commercial flights in Australia. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice. The number of hours that pilots and air crew are able to work on domestic commercial flights in Australia is subject to a number of restrictions. Civil Aviation Order (CAO) 48.0 to 48.4 details the applicable restrictions and a copy of this Order is available on the CASA website at www.casa.gov.au. Foreign Affairs: South-East Asia (Question No. 1645) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 March 2003: (1) Is he able to say whether the Saudi based charity the Islamic International Relief Organisation (IIRO) has, as its South East Asia regional director, Jamal Mohamed Khalifa, who is the brother-inlaw of Osama Bin Laden. (2) Has his attention been drawn to a report titled Tentacles of Terror: Al Qaeda’s Southeast Asian Network, by Dr Zachary Abuza, extracted from a forthcoming book, Terrorism and Radical Islam in Southeast Asia, which claims that Jamal Mohamed Khalifa established other front companies for Al Qaeda/Jemaah Islamiah (JI), including: Khalifa Trading Industries, ET Dizon Travel, Pyramid Trading, Manpower Services and Daw al Iman al Shafee Inc. (3) Does the Australian Government share the view of Dr Abuza, and other analysts, that all of these organisations had the real purpose of supporting Al Qaeda/JI terrorist activities in South-East Asia. (4) Is he able to confirm whether Al Qaeda operative Wali Khan Amin Shah established a shell company, the Bermuda Trading Company, in Malaysia and that Al Qaeda’s chief representative in Malaysia, Ahmad Fauzi, aka Abdul al Hakim, established companies such as: Green Laboratory Medicine SDN BHD, In focus Technology SDN BHD, Secure Valley SDN BHD and Konsojaya SDN BHD, in that country for the purpose of supporting Al Qaeda/JI activities. (1) The Islamic International Relief Organisation (IIRO), a Saudi-based charity, had as its South-East Asian regional director Mohammed Jamal Khalifa. He was subsequently its Philippines director. (2) Yes. (3) The activities of the organisations referred to in question 2 are being investigated by the relevant police and security authorities. It would be inappropriate to comment on matters under investigation. (4) The activities of these organisations and individuals are being investigated by the relevant police and security authorities. It would be inappropriate to comment on matters under investigation.

Telstra: Call Centres (Question No. 1647) Mr Tanner asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 March 2003: (1) Is it the case that the Telstra subsidiary, Sensis, replaced retrenched Sensis staff with outsourced staff from Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd, a joint venture between Telstra and Excell Asia Pacific Pty Ltd; if so, how many Sensis staff were retrenched and how many Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd staff were rehired on an outsourced basis. (2) What payments have been made by Sensis to Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd for the provision of services, and what is the nature of those services. (3) How much money, if any, has Sensis contracted, or budgeted, to provide to Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd in future. (4) Has the Sensis board member and Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd board member, Mr Andrew Day, benefited financially from the provision of any services to Sensis by Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd; if so, what was the full extent of the benefit. (5) Was there a tender process in regard to the provision of services to Sensis by Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd; if so, what was that process. (6) What is the nature and purpose of Telstra’s investment in Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd. has provided the following answer, based on information provided by Telstra, to the honourable member’s question:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(1) No, retrenched Sensis staff were not replaced by Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd staff. Furthermore, no permanent staff were retrenched from Sensis and re-hired through Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd (‘Stellar’). (2) Sensis has two contracts with Stellar for the provision of services. Stellar is providing Sensis with a call centre to answer Yellow Pages® Connect calls. Sensis operates the Yellow Pages® Connect service; which is a premium, advertiser referral service. Details regarding payments by Sensis to Stellar under this contract are commercial-in-confidence. Stellar also provides data entry and call centre services. These services consist of providing timely and accurate maintenance of customer information and directory listings within the Sensis and Telstra databases. Details regarding payments by Sensis to Stellar under this contract are commercialin-confidence. Both of these contracts were rolled over into an umbrella agreement effective from 1 January 2003. (3) Details regarding payments by Sensis to Stellar are commercial-in-confidence. (4) Sensis board member and Stellar board member, Mr Andrew Day, receives no payment or benefit from Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd. Mr Day’s travel costs to attend Stellar Board meetings are paid for by Telstra. (5) For the Yellow Pages® Connect service, Stellar was the only organisation, at the time, with the technological capability suitable to support the Yellow Pages® Connect platform. For the customer operations service in May 2002, Teletech, United Customer Management Solutions and Stellar were invited to respond to a brief detailing Sensis’ requirements for services. Of the three responses received, the Stellar quote was the lowest cost and most suitable. (6) The nature of Telstra’s investment in Stellar Call Centres Pty Ltd is as follows: Stellar is an incorporated joint venture owned 50% by Telstra and 50% by US call centre specialists, Excell Global Services LLC (‘Excell’). Pursuant to the Stellar shareholders agreement, both Telstra and Excell are entitled to appoint three directors. The right to appoint the Chairman is shared between both parties on a rotational basis. In making the decision to invest in Stellar, Telstra’s purpose was to strategically position itself in the expanding call centre market. Defence: Medical Officers (Question No. 1672) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) How many Regular and Reserve General Practitioners are employed in each of the single services. (2) How many Reserve General Practitioners are currently undertaking full-time service in each service. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) The following table represents the number of Medical Officers within Defence by Service. This is a mixture of general duty medical officers, general practitioners and specialist medical officers. Navy Army Air Force Regular 31 101 58 Reserve 156 164 110 The following table represents the number of Medical Officers that possess Fellowship of the Royal Australasian College of General Practitioners within Defence by Service: Navy Army Air Force Regular6 8 4 There are additionally two medical officers vocationally registered for General Practice, one each in Air Force and Army. The number of Reserve General Practitioners (mix of Stand-by and Active) by Service is: Navy Army Air Force Reserve 67 103 16 (2) The numbers of Reserve Medical Officers, who are General Practitioners, currently undertaking full-time service: Navy Army Air Force Reserve2 3 4 Defence: Medical Officers (Question No. 1673) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) How many (a) Service Medical General Practitioners and (b) Service Medical Specialists are currently subject to (i) a formal State Medical Board of Inquiry investigation and (ii) a formal State Medical Board of Inquiry hearing. (2) In each instance, in which Service does the medical practitioner or specialist serve and which State Medical Board is conducting the inquiry or hearing. (3) Has the Surgeon General provided guidance to the Services for doctors subject to State Medical Board inquiries and hearings; if so, what are the details, if not why not. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Defence is only aware of one Service Medical General Practitioner currently subject to a formal State Medical Board of Inquiry investigation and hearing in respect of allegations concerning Australian Defence Force (ADF) medical practice. Additionally one service medical practitioner is the subject of an investigation by a Health Complaints Commissioner. (2) One Navy Reserve Service medical officer is subject to a possible hearing by the Western Australia Medical Board, and one Army Reserve medical officer is subject to an investigation by the Tasmanian Health Complaints Commissioner. (3) The Surgeon General has no role in the provision of guidance to the Services for doctors subject to State Medical Board inquiries. This role is performed by the Director General Defence Health Service (DGDHS) who has issued Health Directive 909 ‘Registration of Australian Defence Force Health Service Professional Officers’. Under this directive, Defence health officers including medical officers are required to notify DGDHS in writing as soon as they are aware that they are subject to investigation or disciplinary proceedings by a professional board in respect of their ADF medical practice. Defence: Medical Officers (Question No. 1674) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) For each service, who approves the deployment doctors and specialists. (2) Is such approval subject to guidance from the Surgeon General; if so, what are the details; if not, why not. (3) Did the Fleet Medical Officer approve the deployment of the doctor on board HMAS Kanimbla. (4) Was the Fleet Medical Officer involved in the case which led to the WA Medical Board of Inquiry investigating and now proceeding to a hearing against the doctor on board HMAS Kanimbla; if so, what steps have been taken to avoid any perception of bias or conflict of interest in the discharge of his or her duty and, if no steps have been taken, why not. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Royal Australian Navy– the posting of doctors to sea, for both general practitioners and specialists, is approved and performed by the Directorate of Naval Officer Postings, noting advice from the Fleet Medical Officer. Royal Australian Army– the Directorate of Officer Career Management and Land Headquarters Health Service would individually or jointly, depending on the situation, approve the deployment of Army doctors and specialists. Royal Australian Air Force– the Officer Commanding Health Services Wing approves the deployment of Doctors and Specialists. (2) No. (3) The posting of the doctor was approved and performed by the Directorate of Naval Officer Postings. The Fleet Medical Officer provided verbal advice that the doctor was available for deployment and was capable of fulfilling the duties required. (4) No. Charlton Electorate: Program Funding (Question No. 1682) Ms Hoare asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs, (b) were these paid advertisements, and if so, (c) what was the cost of each advertisement. (5) What is the name and address of each recipient. I am advised that: (1) The Office of the Status of Women administers the following funding programmes, for which community organisations in any electorate may apply: Policy and capacity building projects under the Women’s Development Programme Initiative, and

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Charlton Electorate: Program Funding (Question No. 1687) Ms Hoare asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs, (b) were these paid advertisements, and if so, (c) what was the cost of each advertisement. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Charlton received funding in (i) 1999, (ii) 2000, (iii) 2001, and (iv) 2002. (5) What is the name and address of each recipient. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts offers the residents of the electorate of Charlton a wide range of benefits across both its cultural and information and communications program streams. These various programs are described in this answer so that they correspond with the structure of the department. ARTS AND SPORT Touring Programs (1) Yes Playing Australia Festivals Australia Contemporary Music Touring Program (2) Yes (a) Each program has two grant rounds per year. A paid block advertisement is placed in all major metropolitan dailies, including The Weekend Australian and The Sydney Morning Herald. These advertisements, under the heading of ‘Cultural Touring Grants’ appear either in the early general news section or the arts pages, usually in late May and late October, after the announcement of successful applicants for the previous round. Festivals Australia rounds are also advertised in more than 60 regional newspapers, 21 of them in New South Wales, including the Newcastle Herald and the Maitland Mercury. This program is also advertised in the NSW & ACT, Special Events Directory. Advertisements are also placed in a number of local government publications on an ad hoc basis. Additional advertisements for the Contemporary Music Touring Program are placed in a selection of ‘street press’ and music industry journals. Information on all programs is accessible off the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts website. State and Territory arts ministries, and Regional Arts Organisations, provide information on the programs via their own publications and/or via website links.

theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(b) Newspaper advertising is paid advertising. Major newspapers Cultural Touring Programs $26,757 per annum Regional newspapers Festivals Australia $15,554 per annum Street press/music industry publications Contemporary Music Touring Program only $3,196 (2002/03) (3) (a) Playing Australia is the Commonwealth Government’s National Performing Arts Touring Program. It is designed to assist the touring of performing arts across State and Territory boundaries where this is currently not commercially viable and there is a demonstrated public demand. Festivals Australia is a funding program designed to assist the presentation of arts and cultural activities at Australian regional and community festivals. The emphasis is on supporting projects, which add to the quality and diversity of the arts and cultural programming of a festival. The Contemporary Music Touring Program aims to develop viable touring opportunities within Australia for Australian musicians, and to increase audience access to live Australian contemporary music, particularly in rural and regional Australia. (b) Expert technical committees, broadly representative of the sector, make recommendations after assessing applications in each round. These are forwarded to the Minister for the Arts and Sport for consideration and approval. (4) One local government organisation received funding under the Festivals Australia Program in 2000. (5) Toronto Chamber of Commerce& Industry Inc PO Box 382 Networking the Nation (1) Yes community organisations could apply for funding through the Commonwealth Networking the Nation (NTN) program. However, individuals and for-profit businesses were not eligible NTN applicants. (2) Yes (a) The Department advertises NTN programs through both paid and non-paid advertisements made through media outlets and standard departmental sources, eg the website and Information Kits. (b) With the exception of editorials where promotional information was provided to media outlets, advertisements were paid for by the Department. (c) In view of the wide variety of regional and national newspapers used for advertising the NTN Programs, and because the Programs have been running for many years (11 funding rounds have been held), I am not prepared to answer, as considerable time and resources would be required to provide the answer to this element of the question. (3) (a) The objective of Networking the Nation is to assist the economic and social development of regional, rural and remote Australia by funding projects which: enhance telecommunications infrastructure and services in regional, rural and remote areas; increase access to, and promote use of, services available through telecommunications networks in regional, rural and remote areas; or reduce disparities in access to such services and facilities between Australians in regional, rural or remote areas and those in urban areas. ‘Regional, rural and remote areas’ are any areas located outside the capital city of each State or Territory. (b) The NTN Board approves funding, which is then released in instalments through funding Deeds administered between recipients and the NTN Secretariat in Canberra. (4) No NTN projects benefited only the electoral division of Charlton. (a) Five NTN projects were managed by organisations based in the electoral division of Charlton. All of these projects benefited the broader Hunter region, including the electoral division of Charlton. title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following an(4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Charlton received funding in (i) 1999, (ii) 2000, (iii) 2001, and (iv) 2002. (5) What is the name and address of each recipient. Mr Ian Macfarlane-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes, community organisations, businesses or individuals in the federal electorate of Charlton are eligible to apply for assistance under the following programs currently administered by the Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, with applications assessed on merit and/or against relevant criteria. Expenditure Programs Shipbuilding Bounty Shipbuilding Innovation Scheme Enhanced Printing Industry Competitiveness Scheme Printing Industry Competitiveness Scheme Small Business Assistance Program (including Small Business Answers, Incubator and Enterprise Culture Programs) TCF Strategic Investment Program R&D Start Grants and Loans (Industry Innovation Program) Commercialising Emerging Technologies (COMET) Program Competitive Pre-Seed Fund Innovation Investment Fund Innovation Access Program National Innovation Awareness Strategy Biotechnology Innovation Fund Regional Tourism Program Renewable Energy Equity Fund Revenue Foregone Programs Automotive Competitiveness and Investment Scheme Expanded Overseas Assembly Provisions Scheme TCF Corporate Wear Program R&D Tax Concession Pooled Development Funds Program Tradex Scheme Enhanced Project By-law Scheme Policy By-law Programs Note: The Department also provides funding for the Supplier Access to Major Projects Program, which is administered by ISONET Pty Ltd. (2) Yes. The programs listed above (with the exception of the National Innovation Awareness Strategy) are delivered by AusIndustry the program delivery arm of the Department. AusIndustry has developed a National Marketing Strategy to facilitate delivery of its programs, which encompasses a range of marketing activities and tools including limited, targeted advertising. Customer inquiries are managed by the AusIndustry delivery framework, including the AusIndustry Hotline and website. These delivery channels provide customers with further information, advice and support in relation to the programs delivered by AusIndustry. AusIndustry has arranged for paid and unpaid advertisements in a number of formats namely, print and radio advertising. Print advertising includes advertisements placed in major daily newspapers (e.g. the Australian and the Sydney Morning Herald), regional newspapers (e.g. the Central Coast Express Advocate and the Newcastle Herald), and targeted sectoral publications (e.g. the Australian CPA Charter when targeting a potential audience of accountants). Local radio advertising in the electoral division of Charlton has included advertisements on Newcastle 2HD, KO FM Newcastle and Gosford 2GO. The AusIndustry operational marketing budget is approximately $1.3 million for the 2002-03 financial year. It provides for the marketing activities delivered under the AusIndustry National Marketing Strategy, including advertising. In relation to the National Innovation Awareness Strategy the most recent advertisements were placed in the weekend Sydney Morning Herald, the Melbourne Age and the Weekend Australian. The aggregate cost of these advertisements was $6,389 (incl. GST). (3) Consolidated information on Departmental programs was forwarded to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee on 25 September 2002, in response to a request made by Senator Campbell during the 2002-03 Budget Estimates hearings. This information, which includes details of the purpose of each program, can be obtained from the Senate Economics Legislation Committee secretariat. Information on Departmental programs is also available on the Department’s website (www.industry.gov.au) and on the AusIndustry website (www.ausindustry.gov.au). A number of the AusIndustry expenditure programs are administered by the Industry Research and Development Board including R&D Start Grants and Loans, Commercialising Emerging Technologies (COMET) Program, Competitive Pre-Seed Fund, Innovation Investment Fund, Biotechnology Innovation Fund and the Renewable Energy Equity Fund. The remaining AusIndustry expenditure programs are administered by AusIndustry with AusIndustry officers acting as delegated decision makers. In relation to the National Innovation Awareness Strategy applications for assistance are initially assessed by a Departmental committee, before being passed to the National Innovation Awareness Council an independent advisory council on innovation for final recommendations on funding. (4) -(5) Information on funding/assistance provided to the electorate of Charlton through these programs in 1999, 2000, 2001 and 2002 is provided below. R&D Start Program: A competitive, merit based grants and loans program that supports businesses to undertake research and development and its commercialisation. Company Name Project Original Date Current Agreed Amount Agreed PCWI Technology Pty Ltd Corrosion Detection 2000 28/10/1999 $126,550 Industrial Automation Services Automated Model Tuning for Metal 18/09/2001 $96,000 Pty Ltd/Uni of Newcastle Finishing Processes Total $222,550 Note: The agreed funding figure reflects total funding allocated to projects. Funding allocated to projects may be paid over a number of years. Small Business Answers Program: Provides funding by way of competitive grants to organisations to deliver advisory services to small business owners and managers across Australia, particularly in regional areas not already serviced by existing advisory bodies. Company Name Project Original Date Current Agreed Amount Agreed Hunter Area Consultative To provide advisory service to small 21/03/03 $268,000 Committee business in the local government areas of Lake Macquarie, Port Stephens, Maitland, Cessnock, Dungog, Singleton, Muswellbrook, Scone, Merriwa and Murrurundi Total $268,000 Enhanced Printing Industry Competitiveness Scheme: A competitive grants program to enhance the competitiveness of firms in the Australian book production industry by encouraging innovation, infrastructure and business development, and skills formation. Company Name Project Original Date Agreed Current Agreed Amount Nightingale Press Pty Ltd Business Plan 21/03/01 $54,010 Nightingale Press Pty Ltd Development of Electronic 18/02/03 $98,080 Data Interface Total $152,090 R&D Tax Concession: A broad-based market driven tax concession which allows companies to deduct up to 125% of qualifying expenditure incurred on eligible R&D activities when lodging their corporate tax return. A 175 per cent Premium (Incremental) Tax Concession and R&D Tax Offset are also available in certain circumstances. Company Details Financial Year Eligible R&D Expenditure Number of companies: 32 1999/00 $9,863,175 Number of companies: 34 2000/01 $11,517,841 Number of companies: 26 2001/02 $11,788,361 Total $33,169,377 Note: Section 47 of the IR&D Act precludes the disclosure of information relating to individual tax payers. The information provided is an aggregate of the total expenditure companies in the electorate of Charlton have registered to claim in the relevant financial years. The actual benefit received by individual tax payers is confidential and only known to the Australian Taxation Office. Project By-Laws Scheme: Provides import duty concessions on capital equipment used in major projects in mining, resource processing, manufacturing and agriculture-based industries. Company Details Financial Year Duty Foregone Aggregate information provided 2001/02 $73,925 Total $73,925 Note: The information provided is an aggregate of the total revenue foregone in respect of companies in the electorate of Charlton. Confidentiality restrictions prevent disclosure of detailed information. Tradex: Provides financial relief to exporting companies via an up-front exemption from customer duty and GST on imported goods intended for re-export or to be used as inputs to exports. Company Details Financial Year Duty Foregone Aggregate information provided 2000/01 $7,855 2001/02 $23,808 2002/03 $582 Total $32,245 Note: The information provided is an aggregate of the total revenue foregone in respect of companies in the electorate of Charlton. Confidentiality restrictions prevent disclosure of detailed information. Charlton Electorate: Program Funding (Question No. 1699) Ms Hoare asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Charlton can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs, (b) were these paid advertisements, and if so, (c) what was the cost of each advertisement. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) businesses or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Charlton received funding in (i) 1999, (ii) 2000, (iii) 2001, and (iv) 2002. (5) What is the name and address of each recipient. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes, the programs are: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program; Veteran& Community Grants; Saluting Their Service Commemorations program; and Grants-in-Aid. (2) (a), (b) and (c) The details of promoting the BEST, Veteran& Community Grants and Saluting Their Service Commemorations programs are shown below. No advertising is undertaken with the Grants-in-Aid program but the application form is available on the Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program The Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the website. Annual forums are held by Department of Veterans’ Affairs State Deputy Commissioners with various peak ex-service organisation representatives to address BEST funding for the coming financial year. From these forums, peak ex-service organisation representatives advise their members of funding arrangements. The Training Information Program (TIP). Information on the BEST program is incorporated into some TIP training sessions held in the States. A letter mail out advising of forthcoming BEST application periods. The mail out is circulated to existing grantees notifying them of forthcoming BEST funding. There are no paid advertisements for this program. Veteran& Community Grants The Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the website. The Grantslink website. A Commonwealth government grants website which is managed by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. The Department of Veterans’ Affairs State Office staff, Veterans’ Affairs Network (VAN) Office staff and Community Advisers. Information about Veteran& Community Grants are disseminated at this level through local visits, forums (such as ex-service organisation grant workshops), mail outs and newsletter articles directed at ex-service and targeted community organisations. There are no paid advertisements for this program. Saluting Their Service Commemorations Program The Department of Veterans’ Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the website. The Grantslink website. A Commonwealth government grants website which is managed by the Department of Transport and Regional Services. A mail out to all Federal Members and Senators. Brochures are available from offices of the Department of Veterans’ Affairs. The only paid advertisement for this program is in the Australian Local Government Yearbook (2002) which the cost was $2,000. (3) (a) The purpose of each of the programs is: Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program – The aim of this program is to provide support and resources to ex-service organisation practitioners for pension and welfare work to assist veterans and widow(er)s. Veteran& Community Grants– These grants aim to maintain and improve the independence and quality of life of members of the veteran community. The grants provide funding for projects which promote healthier lifestyles and enhance health, support carers, reduce social isolation and assist veterans and war widow(er)s to remain in their own homes as long as possible. Projects may also generate benefits for the wider community. Organisations that can demonstrate a contribution to the welfare of members of the veteran community are eligible to apply for funding. Saluting Their Service Commemorations Program– This program honours the contribution of Australia’s servicemen and women in wars, conflicts and peace operations. Grants may be approved under the program for the restoration, preservation and upgrading of community war memorials or, where no memorial exists in the town or suburb, the construction of a new memorial; the restoration, preservation and interpretation of Australian wartime memorabilia for public display; commemoration of significant anniversaries of battles and other military operations; significant reunions of units; and school initiatives, eg research projects involving local veterans. The maximum generally available is $4,000. Grants-in-Aid– The aim of this program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that they provide to the ex-service community. (b) The Minister for Veterans’ Affairs. (4) (a), (b) and (c) The number of community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Charlton who received funding in 1999 to 2002 is: 1999* Program Community Business Individual Organisation BEST Veteran& Community Grants Saluting Their Service1 Program Community Business Individual Organisation Grants-in-Aid 2000* Program Community Business Individual Organisation BEST Veteran& Community Grants Saluting Their Service1 Grants-in-Aid 2001* Program Community Business Individual Organisation BEST Veteran& Community Grants2 Saluting Their Service1 3 Grants-in-Aid 2002* Program Community Business Individual Organisation BEST 1 Veteran& Community Grants1 Saluting Their Service1 Grants-in-Aid *The electorate of Charlton has not received any funding from the Grants-in-Aid program for 1999, 2000, 2001 and 2002, since there are no national ex-service organisations presently located in the electorate. It is possible that national ex-service organisations may have dispersed part of their Grant-in-Aid to sub-branches within the electorate. (5) The name and address of the community organisation recipients is as follows: Name Address Boolaroo Speers Point RSL Sub-branch PO Box 20 Boolaroo NSW 2284 Cardiff RSL Sub-branch PO Box 374 Cardiff NSW 2285 Ex-Services Memorial Centre Newcastle-Lake Macquarie PO Box 299 Toronto NSW 2283 Combined Schools ANZAC Committee Lake Macquarie PO Box 194 Boolaroo NSW 2284 The Hammond Care Group New South Wales Level3 283 George Street Sydney NSW 2000 The names and addresses of the three individual recipients have not been disclosed for privacy reasons. Foreign Affairs: Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (Question No. 1701) Mr Rudd asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 March 2003: (1) Can he provide details of the occasions since March 1996 when he has described the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK) as a threat to Australia’s security. (2) Can he provide details of the Governments assessment of: (a) the number of (i) nuclear weapons warheads, (ii) chemical weapons warheads and (iii) biological weapons warheads, and (b) the number of missiles including: (i) the type, and (ii) their range, in the DPRK’s possession. (1) I have on many occasions referred to the DPRK as a threat to Australia’s security. Recent instances include: on 10 March 2003 I wrote in the International Herald Tribune, ‘… any move by the North to reprocess its spent reactor fuel rods to extract plutonium’, or ‘… launching a long-range ballistic missile…’ ‘… would destabilise the region and have global ramifications.’ on 2 March 2003, on Channel 10’s Meet the PressI said ‘(Iraq and DPRK)…are both very substantial threats to international security and that includes Australia.’ on 28 February 2003, in an interview with Tricia Duffield on radio 2SM, I said the DPRK ‘is quite a threat.’ on 27 February 2003, in a doorstop interview, I said ‘if North Korea is going to continue to develop its nuclear program and… missile systems… that’s a major security threat to the AsiaPacific Region as well as the world beyond.’ on 12 February 2003 during Question Time in the House of Representatives, I said ‘We do see it (the DPRK) as a serious threat to regional security.’ on 3 January 2003, in The AgeI wrote ‘The ramifications of an overt and expanding nuclear weapons program in North Korea would be disastrous for the Asia-Pacific region and beyond … The region would be destabilised and global resources would be diverted.’ on 11 March 2003, the Joint Ministerial Statement of the Sixth Australia-Indonesia Ministerial Forum ‘expressed serious concern at the threat to regional and global security posed by the DPRK’s nuclear program.’ (2) (a) (i) While it is difficult to be certain that North Korea actually has nuclear weapons the Government’s assessment is that it could have enough weapons-grade fissile material for one or two, or possibly three nuclear weapons; (ii) & (iii) North Korea is thought to be developing or already has chemical and biological weapons but there is no detailed information available on actual DPRK holdings of these weapons. (b) North Korea is thought to have large numbers of Scud and No-Dong missiles. The Scuds have estimated ranges of 300-500 kms, while the No-Dong has a range of 1300 kms. North Korea also continues to develop an inter-continental ballistic missile (ICBM), the Taepo Dong-2. The range of the Taepo Dong-2 would depend on configuration and payload but could go as high as 15,000 kms. Operational deployment of the Taepo Dong-2 is probably still some years away. Iraq (Question No. 1703) Mr Rudd asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) Can he advise whether AusAID has had any contact with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) or other UN bodies on the matter of Iraqi refugees arising from a potential conflict with Iraq; if so, what are the details (dates, time, locations, and with whom) of those dealings.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Can he advise whether AusAID has had any contact with UN organisations on the matter of postwar reconstruction efforts in Iraq; if so, what were those organisations, and what are the details (dates, time, locations, with whom and content) of that contact. (1) Prior to the 19th March 2003, AusAID officials held a number of sessions with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), the International Organisation of Migration (IOM) and other United Nations representatives in Geneva, New York and Canberra. In addition, there was substantial e-mail, correspondence and general briefing sessions between AusAID officials and the various UN agencies. (2) Prior to the 19th March 2003, AusAID officials had regular contact with various United Nations organisations including United Nations Development Program (UNDP); World Health Organisation (WHO); Organisation for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on potential reconstruction priorities and activities in Iraq. These meetings were held primarily in Geneva, New York and Canberra. AusAID contact with these organisations was primarily the provision of general briefing information of a regional and country specific nature, organisation preparedness planning and the potential mobilisation of Australian aid personnel to post-war Iraq. Health and Ageing: Nursing Homes (Question No. 1704) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) Has he engaged in consultations with Baptist Community Care concerning the proposed closure of the Church Nursing Home in Blyth Street, Brunswick, and has he engaged in consultations with anyone else regarding this issue; if so, with whom. (2) Did the Commonwealth provide capital assistance for the Church Nursing Home before, during, or after its construction in 1995; if so, (a) what was the value of that capital assistance, (b) were there any conditions attached to the provisions of that assistance and (c) will the Commonwealth be seeking a refund of any or all of that capital assistance. (3) Does the Government have any policy to ensure that capital assistance for nursing homes is not wasted; for example, if a nursing home constructed with Commonwealth funds were proposed to be demolished after 30 days is there any action the Commonwealth could take to prevent this. (4) Does the Government have any policy concerning the re-allocation of bed licences; for example, if a body which has an allocation of bed licences sought to transfer those licences to a facility in an area of lesser need, would the Government allow this; if so, in what circumstances. (5) Has he received representations from the Member for Gippsland concerning Baptist Community Care nursing home facilities; if so, what action did he take following those representations. (1) No. (2) Yes; the Commonwealth provided a capital grant to the Church Nursing Home in June 1994; (a) $891,000, (b) yes, (c) the Grant Agreement provides that the Organisation shall not at any time, demolish or sell or otherwise dispose of or mortgage or encumber any part of the approved home or any part of the land on which the approved home is situated, without the approval in writing of the Secretary. The Secretary may, in giving approval, impose such conditions as the Secretary sees fit. In making a decision on whether to make repayment of part or the entire grant a condition of the Secretary’s approval of sale, all relevant circumstances surrounding the sale will be considered. (3) Yes.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) The allocation of aged care places is governed by the Aged Care Act 1997 (the Act), which contains provisions relating to the transfer of aged care places from one provider to another and the variation of conditions of allocation of places, e.g. from one locality to another. If a provider wishes to vary the location at which aged care places are available, the provider must apply to the Department of Health and Ageing for approval to do so. Each application is considered in accordance with criteria specified in the Act and in the Allocations Principles 1997. For variations of the conditions of allocation, in deciding whether the variation is justified in the circumstances, the Department must consider whether the variation would meet the objectives of the aged care planning process specified in the Act. (5) Yes; representations have been received from both the Member for Gippsland and the Member for Macmillan. The Members were advised that if the Approved Provider wished to seek capital funding it would need to apply to the Department of Health and Ageing through the annual Aged Care Approvals Round. Ministerial Staff: Travel Allowance (Question No. 1706) Ms Roxon asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 19 March 2003: (1) Were the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs’ staff members, Mr Peter McConnell and Mr Damian Callachor acting on the Minister’s directions during their two day trip to the Richmond electorate on 11 and 12 March 2003; if not, under whose direction were they acting. (2) Did the Commonwealth Government initially pay the airfares from Canberra to the electoral division of Richmond for the 2 staff members concerned; if so (a) what was the cost of those flights and (b) has the cost of these flights been repaid; if so when. (3) Did any staff members of the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs claim Travel Allowance for the night of 11 March 2003; if so, has this allowance been repaid to the Commonwealth; if so, when. (4) Can the Minister confirm that a hire car was authorised for two members of the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs’ staff for the night of 11 March 2003 and can the Minister also confirm that these payments have now been repaid; if so, on what date was this repayment received by the Commonwealth. (5) Who authorised the payment of the hire car and under which Member or Senator’s entitlement was it initially paid. (6) Will taxpayer funds be used by any of the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs’ staff to attend a court hearing on 7 April at Tweed Heads in respect of an incident on 11 March 2003. ourable member’s question: (1) I am unable to comment on directions given to staff of another Minister by that Minister. (2) Yes. (a) $1,725.80. (b) No. (3) (a)Yes. (b) No. (4) Yes. Repayment was received on 4 April 2003. (5) Payment was authorised by the Department of Finance and Administration in accordance with established procedures. The payment was made against staff car hire for the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs. (6) The Department of Finance and Administration has no records which indicate that taxpayer funds were used.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Abbott
theText: The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honImmigration: Asylum Seekers (Question No. 1708) Mr Andren asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 2003: In respect of each death of an asylum seeker in detention in International Organization for Migration (IOM) administered camps established with Australian funding in Nauru and Papua New Guinea, or in a hospital or other place to which they were removed from an IOM camp; (a) what investigations have been undertaken, (b) what was the cause of the death and (c) how was the cause of death established. There has only been one death of an asylum seeker in the International Organization for Migration (IOM) managed offshore processing centres since these centres were established in late 2001. Media reports claimed that an Iraqi asylum seeker had died on Nauru in March after a period of isolation from other residents. These reports were unfounded. In respect of the only death on Nauru: (a) The Nauru Coroner ordered that an autopsy be conducted to determine the cause of death. The autopsy was conducted on Nauru by the Head of the Division of Pathology, Victorian Institute of Forensic Medicine. (b) and (c) Despite an extensive post mortem examination, which included microscopic and toxicological analysis, the pathologist was unable to determine the precise cause of death in this case. The pathologist’s report, however, found that there was nothing to indicate death was due to anything other than natural causes. The Nauru Coroner found that the death was as a result of natural causes. Member for Macarthur: Newsletter Allowance (Question No. 1712) Mr Latham asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 20 March 2003: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports in the Macarthur Advertiser on 12 February 2003, stating that Mr Pat Farmer, MP, repaid almost $700 last week after breaching government guidelines relating to the use of his taxpayer-funded newsletter. (2) Can the Minister confirm that the Member for Macarthur breached the guidelines and that the Minister requested repayment; if so, what are the details. (3) Can the Minister confirm that the Member for Macarthur has now repaid $700 for the misuse of his newsletter allowance; if so, (a) on what date was the repayment received, and (b) is he able to say whether the repayment was made from a campaign fund or by the Member personally. (4) Can the Minister explain on what basis or by what calculation this amount of money was determined. ourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) No. (3) No. However Mr Farmer made a voluntary contribution of $668 in relation to his electorate newsletter that was printed and distributed in the Macarthur Advertiser newspaper on 13 November
