theText: The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the hon2002. (a) 5 February 2003. (b) The payment was in the form of a personal cheque from Mr Farmer. (4) Mr Farmer made a voluntary contribution of $668 based on his assessment of the proportion of allegedly party political material (7%) that was contained in the newsletter – as has occurred on previous occasions with Labor Party and Senators and Members. Rural and Regional Australia: Flood Mitigation Program (Question No. 1718) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: (1) Further to the answers to question No. 1176 (Hansard, 4 February 2003, page 168) and question No. 1376 (Hansard, 18 March 2003, page 12646) why has Parramatta City Council received funding of $950,000 pursuant to the Governments Regional Flood Mitigation Program (RFMP), considering only three houses have been earmarked for voluntary purchase in the Wentworthville area. (2) Is the Government aware that the Fairfield City Council has identified 330 houses that require raising. (3) Is the Government aware that the Fairfield City Council has identified 93 houses for voluntary purchase, of which 73 have been purchased and will the Government make enquiries about the purchase of the remaining 20. (4) Has the Government received requests from the Fairfield City Council for flood mitigation funding since 2000; if so, how many and what was the Governments response to each request. (5) Is the Government willing to reassess the costs of flooding in metropolitan areas; if so, will the Government attempt to re-establish a metropolitan flood mitigation scheme; if not, why not. (1) I am advised that Parramatta City Council is one of several NSW local councils to share in a statewide voluntary purchase allocation of $950,000 in Federal Government funds in 2002-2003. This funding is not for the sole benefit of Parramatta City Council, and the final amount to be allocated to the Council is yet to be finalised by the NSW State Government. (2) and (3) While the Federal Government does not have an in-depth knowledge of the current status of Fairfield City Council’s house raising and voluntary purchase projects, it is aware of the overall magnitude of the flood problem facing Council. Flood mitigation, however, is essentially a State Government responsibility and the priority to be given to the purchase of the remaining 20 houses in Fairfield is a matter for Council to address with the NSW State Government. (4) I am advised that Fairfield City Council has not submitted any formal expressions of interest or applications for funding under the RFMP. (5) The Federal Government has no plans to re-establish a metropolitan flood mitigation scheme. Flood mitigation is essentially a State Government responsibility and metropolitan areas have a significantly greater capacity to pay for local measures from their rates base. Immigration: Detention Centres (Question No. 1721) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2003:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) In respect of this announcement on 19 March 2003 that the temporary immigration detention centre on Christmas Island has been mothballed, why were the three people transferred to Nauru and not to an Australian immigration detention centre. (2) In respect of the three people transferred to Nauru: (a) when did they first arrive at Christmas Island, (b) what are their nationalities, (c) to which camp on Nauru have they been transferred, (d) what was the status of their applications for refugee status at the time they were transferred, and (e) who will be conducting the remainder of the assessments of their refugee status. (1) Under s198A of the Migration Act the people in question are offshore entry persons who entered Australia at Christmas Island, an excised offshore place after the excision time for that place and became unlawful non-citizens because of their entry. As Offshore Entry Persons they were transferred to Nauru as they had declined the Afghan reintegration package or were waiting for removal to their country of origin. Nauru was declared on 2 October 2001 under the requirements of s198A (3) of the Act. (2) (a) The three detainees arrived on separate boats at various locations. The first detainee arrived at Christmas Island on 30 October 2001, the second detainee arrived 14 November 2001 and the third on 28 May 2002. (b) Two claim to be Afghan nationals and the other claims to be a Bangladeshi national. (c) The three detainees arrived in Nauru on Wednesday 19 March 2003 and entered the Topside Offshore Processing Centre. (d) At the time of transfer to Nauru the two Afghan nationals had received Refugee Status Determination (RSD) both at primary and review stages and had been determined not to be refugees. The Bangladeshi national did not prima facie engage protection obligations. The RSD is a system developed for processing unauthorised arrivals seeking protection who are on an excised offshore place or in a declared country. The RSD is modelled on the refugee assessment processes of the UNHCR. (e) As indicated above, all three detainees have been assessed as not engaging protection obligations or other international treaty obligations. No humanitarian considerations were presented by these people. The three people are awaiting removal or repatriation as soon as circumstances permit. Roads: Tugan Bypass (Question No. 1722) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Acting Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: (1) In respect of the Tugan bypass: (a) when is it expected that the final bypass route will be selected, (b) what is the expected cost of the C4 bypass route, (c) when is it expected that construction of the bypass will commence, and (d) what is the expected time scale for completion of the project. (2) Is the Commonwealth contribution of $120 million capped and, if the New South Wales Government chooses not to contribute, has it been agreed that the Queensland Government will meet the full cost of completing the bypass. (3) Over which financial years will the Commonwealth Government contribute the promised $120 million to the project and how much money will be paid in each financial year. (1) In respect of the Tugun bypass. (a) The Federal Government has agreed to leave route selection to the Queensland Government. I am advised that unless planning and environmental issues cause
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:delays, it is probable that a route will be selected shortly. (b) The total cost of the C4 route is yet to be finalised. (c) The Queensland Government announced in November 2002 that it would commence construction of Stage1 in late 2003. I understand that Queensland intends to commence construction as soon as all the necessary approvals have been received. (d) It is too early to give an accurate estimate on the time scale of this project due to the planning issues to be resolved. (2) In Mr Anderson’s agreement with the Queensland Government, Queensland has acknowledged that the Commonwealth’s funding is capped at $120 million and contingent on the construction of the complete bypass from the Pacific Motorway to the Pacific Highway, regardless of whether the New South Wales Government contributes. (3) The Commonwealth Government has agreed to commence funding in the 2006-07 financial year. The money to be paid in each financial year will depend on the timing of the project and budgetary considerations, details of which will not become available until at least the planning for Stage2 is complete. Transport: Heavy Vehicles (Question No. 1728) Mr Ripoll asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: (1) Did the Government increase the excise on diesel fuel on 1 January 2003. (2) Did the Government simultaneously increase the on-road diesel fuel rebate for the transport industry. (3) Will BDouble vehicles be denied access to the Pacific Highway; if so, will more rest areas be provided to cater for the increase in the number of heavy vehicles using the Pacific Highway. (4) When will the mass management scheme become national. (1) No. (2) No. (3) The assessment of routes for B-double access and the provision of rest areas on the Pacific Highway are responsibilities of State Governments. (4) The National Heavy Vehicle Accreditation Scheme (NHVAS), which includes a mass management module, has been agreed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Transport Ministers for adoption on a national basis. The Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory have either implemented higher mass limits. Roads: Ipswich Motorway (Question No. 1729) Mr Ripoll the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: (1) What plans does the Government have to improve the terrible road conditions and traffic problems of the Ipswich motorway. (2) Does the Government acknowledge the severely bad condition of the Ipswich motorway and accept responsibility for the occurrence of regular accidents, danger to property and lives and for the damage to the Ipswich economy. (3) Does the Government acknowledge that the Ipswich motorway is a federally funded road.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) Is it the case that the Government funded a $2 million master plan for the Ipswich motorway prepared by the Queensland Government; if so, when will the Federal Government act on the plan’s recommendations. (5) When will the Government make a commitment to fund the much-needed works and upgrade the Ipswich motorway. (1) and (2) The Federal and State Governments are working together to develop an interim package of works to ease congestion and improve safety on the Ipswich Motorway, while longer term options are explored. The interim works package is nearing finalisation and will be funded by the $64 million committed in May 2001 by the Federal Government for the Ipswich Motorway. (3) Under current road funding arrangements the Ipswich Motorway is Federally funded. (4) The Federal Government has so far provided $4.3 million for the planning study for the Ipswich Motorway and the Federal and State Governments have agreed to work together in properly examining all possible solutions to traffic problems along this corridor. (5) The Federal and State Governments are working together to develop a long-term solution for this corridor for consideration under future Commonwealth funding arrangements. Iraq (Question No. 1730) Mr Ripoll asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: Given the Federal Government’s strong and formal condemnation of Iraq regarding that country’s production and stockpiling of weapons of mass destruction, is the Federal Government going to: (a) formally condemn North Korea for its production and stockpiling of weapons of mass destruction, and (b) condemn any other nations that stockpile weapons of mass destruction; if not, on what basis is that policy decision made. (a) The Government has on numerous occasions put on record its serious concerns about North Korea’s suspected weapons of mass destruction (WMD) programs and has deplored in the strongest terms North Korea’s breaches of its nuclear non-proliferation obligations. (b) The Government has been unequivocal in making known its strong opposition to stockpiling of weapons of mass destruction in breach of international legal obligations. Veterans: Entitlements (Question No. 1737) Mr Ripoll asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: (1) How does the Federal Government support and compensate veterans for any trauma they suffer. (2) Is she able to say how many veterans will be entitled to full government support after having served in Iraq. (3) Is she able to estimate the future cost to the Government of supporting veterans of the Iraq war. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) If a serviceperson is injured, develops an illness or dies as a consequence of defence service, the Military Compensation Scheme provides benefits under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRCA). Additionally, where the claim arises from a period of operational service, compensation and health care may be provided under the Veterans’ Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA). In the latter case, offsetting provisions apply so that the same injury / incapacity is not compen-
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:sated twice. Under the Defence Act 1903 additional amounts of compensation is payable to those who are severely injured, or to the families of those who die, in compensable circumstances. (2) All Australian Defence Force personnel allotted for service with Operation Falconer who serve in the operational area will be eligible for the full range of benefits. (3) No, the future cost is dependent on the rate of claims which may arise from service in Operation Falconer. Iraq (Question No. 1740) Ms Vamvakinou asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: In respect of possible military action in Iraq: (a) does the government support the use by the United States of cluster bombs in Iraq, and (b) has Australia sought the commitment of the US to aid and finance the clean up of such munitions. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (a) The Government has been prepared to accept a judgement by the United States that a cluster munition might be the most effective way to achieve specific military objective. (b) No. The post-conflict humanitarian relief and reconstruction of Iraq is an undertaking for the international community as a whole, and the clearance of the explosive remnants of war will form part of that undertaking. Immigration: Detention Centres (Question No. 1742) Ms Vamvakinou asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 2003: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 957 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8755) has he considered implementing a nation-wide protocol for all immigration detention centres in relation to the request for sanitary products and their distribution to female detainees. (2) Will he consider expanding the conditions relating to the provision of sanitary products to female detainees as in the Baxter detention centre, to all other detention centres. (1) Under the Immigration Detention Standards, Australasian Correctional Management (ACM) is required to operate in a manner that preserves the dignity and privacy of all detainees including females. Request and distribution arrangements for sanitary products are therefore established to ensure that female detainees can be provided with their sanitary products in the most discreet manner possible. Each Immigration Detention Facility has individual arrangements in place for the distribution of sanitary products to female immigration detainees. These arrangements are tailored to meet the needs of female detainees at each centre and the arrangements take into account the physical layout (infrastructure) of each centre, the composition of ACM staff (availability of female ACM officers) and the profile of the detainee population. It is for this reason that implementing a nation-wide protocol for all immigration detention centres in relation to the request for sanitary products and their distribution to female detainees would likely prove difficult. (2) The conditions relating to the provision of sanitary products to female detainees in the Baxter detention centre when compared to all other detention centres, are similar.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:In some of the other centres (see below), such as Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre, and the Maribyrnong and Perth Immigration Detention Centres, there are no restrictions on the supply of sanitary products or on the number of requests. Any differences between the arrangements operating at each centre are due to the physical layout (infrastructure) of each centre, the composition of ACM staff (availability of female ACM officers) and the profile of the detainee population. It is for these reasons that expanding the conditions relating to the provision of sanitary products to female detainees in the Baxter detention centre, to all other centres, may not be practicable. The individual arrangements operating at each centre are as follows: Baxter Immigration Detention Facility Upon verbal request to a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member all female detainees are provided with sanitary napkins from a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member. ACM has advised that tampons are provided on request. However, tampons are not generally a popular product among the female detainee population. Female detainees are given a three months supply of sanitary products at the time of each request. They may seek further supplies when they foresee that their three months supply will run out. Sanitary products may be obtained from the nurse who is located at the nurses’ station in their compound. Sanitary products are supplied in discreet bags. Perth Immigration Detention Centre Various sanitary products are available to all female detainees. There is no restriction on the supply of sanitary products. There is no restriction on the number of requests. Sanitary products are supplied by the nurse. ACM officers are not involved. Port Hedland Immigration Reception and Processing Centre Female detainees are able to access sanitary products by requesting the products from ACM Welfare Officers. Sanitary pads are supplied by ACM to female detainees, or they may purchase tampons from the shop if they wish. Once a request has been made, a female detainee is provided with one packet of sanitary pads. Detainees may submit requests as often as necessary. Female detainees submit a request to an ACM Welfare Officer in order to obtain sanitary pads. Female detainees can collect sanitary pads from the ACM Welfare Officer on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre Sanitary products are available in each compound from the ACM administration office block which houses provisions for the detainees. There is always at least one female ACM officer on duty. There is no limit placed on the number of pads or tampons available for distribution. Female detainees may request sanitary products as often as necessary. Female detainees may request sanitary products from a female ACM officer in the compound, as there is always at least one female officer on duty. Sanitary products are issued in packages that are discreetly wrapped. Woomera Residential Housing Project Women go to the main office at the RHP and request pads. Pads are freely issued by the women detention officers. Products are issued discreetly. Sanitary napkins are provided as tampons are not popular with the female detainees. Women are provided with an unopened pack of pads when requested. Christmas Island Immigration Reception and Processing Centre Sanitary products are stored at the ACM officer post in Charlie block dormitory. A small supply of sanitary products is also stored in the medical clinic. Upon request to a female ACM officer or female nursing staff member, a female detainee is provided with sufficient products to last five to six days. Most requests are for sanitary napkins, not tampons. There is no restriction on the number of requests made. Female detainees may either speak to medical staff, or to an ACM female officer, or they may request the products in writing. Either medical staff or female ACM officers provide the sanitary products to the detainees. Villawood Immigration Detention Centre As the majority of female detainees are housed in LIMA compound, which is fully staffed by ACM female officers, sanitary products are stored in the compound. Sanitary pads are issued five or six at a time (the female detainees have indicated that this is their preference), while tampons are provided in sealed packs of ten. Sanitary products are provided when required and on request. Female detainees, including those in the general compound, verbally request sanitary products from a female ACM LIMA compound staff officer. Pads are issued in discreet bags, while the tampon packs are small enough to be placed in a pocket or small bag. Maribyrnong Immigration Detention Centre Sanitary products are available from the ACM female dormitory officer. There is no restriction on the supply of sanitary products. There is no restriction on the number of requests. Female detainees can request sanitary products from the ACM female dormitory officer. Sanitary products are delivered to the detainees by hand. Products are also available in the kitchen. Curtin Immigration Reception and Processing Centre (now closed) Sanitary napkins were supplied upon request. Tampons were not popular with the female detainees. Supply was consistent with detainees’ monthly requirements, with a slight oversupply rather than undersupply of the products to the detainees occurring as a general rule, in order to ensure detainees’ needs were fully met. When required or anticipated to be required. Female detainees would attend the welfare area where products were dispensed through the assistance of a female detainee who assisted ACM staff in the area. Supplies were delivered in discreet bags. theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(2) The following table shows the number of Medicare services provided during (a) 2001-02 and (b) 2002-03 in (i) Victoria, (ii) the electoral division of Calwell, and (iii) in the postcode areas of (a) 3036,(b) 3037, (c) 3038, (d) 3043, (e) 3046 (f) 3047, (g) 3048, (h) 3049, (i) 3059, (j) 3060, (k) 3061, (l) 3064, (m) 3427 and (n) 3428: Financial Year Victoria Calwell Selected Postcodes* 2001-02 55,148,170 972,982 1,286,871 Jul– Dec 2002 28,275,514 488,015 647,494 * Selected Postcodes are: 3036, 3037, 3038, 3043, 3046, 3047, 3048, 3049, 3059, 3060, 3061, 3064, 3427 and 3428 (3) The following table shows the number of Medicare services provided per capita during (a) 2001-02 and (b) 2002-03 in (i) Victoria, (ii) the electoral division of Calwell, and (iii) in the postcode areas of (a) 3036,(b) 3037, (c) 3038, (d) 3043, (e) 3046, (f) 3047, (g) 3048, (h) 3049, (i) 3059, (j) 3060, (k) 3061, (l) 3064, (m) 3427, and (n) 3428 Financial Year Victoria Calwell Selected Postcodes* 2001-02 11.30 5.62 5.90 Jul– Dec 2002 5.76 2.80 2.95 * Selected Postcodes are: 3036, 3037, 3038, 3043, 3046, 3047, 3048, 3049, 3059, 3060, 3061, 3064, 3427 and 3428 The statistics relate to services rendered on a ‘fee-for-service’ basis for which Medicare benefits were paid in the periods in question (based on date of processing). Excluded are details of services to public patients in hospital, to Department of Veterans’ Affairs patients and some compensation cases. The statistics in question were based on data captured at the servicing provider postcode level. In compiling statistics for the electoral division of Calwell, since some postcodes overlap Federal electoral division boundaries, statistics by servicing provider postcode were mapped to electorate using data from the Census of Population and Housing showing the proportion of the population of each postcode in each Federal electoral division. The nominated selected postcodes do not coincide precisely with those postcodes/portions of postcodes which make up the electoral division of Calwell. United Nations Human Rights Commission (Question No. 1753) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 2003: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1408 (Hansard, 18 March 2003, page 12792), which countries: (a) voted in favour, (b) voted against and (c) abstained. (2) Why did Australia abstain. (3) Does he agree with the statement of Colonel Qadhafis son, Seif al-Islam Qadhafi, reported in the International Herald Tribune on 22 January 2003, that Libya was uniquely placed to fulfil the role because of its history as a gross violator of human rights. (1) The vote was by secret ballot.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) There is a well-established principle of accepting by consensus any uncontested candidate from a regional group for a position to be held by that group. The government considers the voting on such positions risks politicising CHR and reducing its effectiveness in addressing human rights concerns. (3) Australia’s deep concern about the human rights situation in Libya is well known. The government takes the view that constructive engagement in the international human rights framework by any country can have a positive effect on its human rights situation. Health: National Diabetes Services Scheme (Question No. 1756) Ms Jackson the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 March 2003: Is the Department of Health and Ageing considering whether or not to list insulin pump consumables on the National Diabetes Services Scheme; if not, why not; if so, is the Minister able to say when the Department will make its decision. the honourable member’s question: Yes. My Department will be putting recommendations to me once it has completed an assessment of the clinical and cost effectiveness of insulin pump consumables compared to other available products. Hasluck Electorate: Tough On Drugs Strategy (Question No. 1757) Ms Jackson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 March 2003: Since the beginning of the “Tough On Drugs” program; (a) which projects based in the electoral division of Hasluck have received funding under the program, (b) how much funding has each project received, and (c) which agency is responsible for each project. the honourable member’s question: (a) Northeast Metropolitan Community Drug Service Team and North East Region Youth Council, Midland receive funding under “Tough on Drugs”. (b) The Northeast Metropolitan Community Drug Service Team service receives retainer funding totalling $69,375 per annum. The North East Region Youth Council, Midland, has received a total of $200,000 over four years. (c) The agencies responsible are Holyoake (The Australian Institute on Alcohol and Addictions) which operates the Northeast Metropolitan Community Drug Service Team and the North East Region Youth Council, Midland. Hasluck Electorate: Internet Broadband Access (Question No. 1759) Ms Jackson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 March 2003: (1) Which of the following suburbs in the electoral division of Hasluck have: (a) total access, (b) partial access, or (c) no access at all to Telstra’s Internet ADSL Broadband technology: Bellevue, Castle Glen, Caversham, Crestwood, Forest Lakes, Forrestfield, Gooseberry Hill, Gosnells, Guildford, Hazelmere, Helena Valley, High Wycombe, Huntingdale, Kalamunda, Kenwick, Koongamia, Les-
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer tomurdie, Maddington, Maida Vale, Martin, Middle Swan, Midland, Midvale, Orange Grove, South Guildford, Thornlie, Viveash, Walliston, Wattle Grove, West Swan and Woodbridge. (2) In respect of each suburb which is currently unable to access Telstra’s Internet broadband technology, is the Minister able to; (a) confirm whether or not this is due to existing pair gaining technology; if not, what is the reason for lack of access, and (b) say when they will be able to access Telstra’s Internet ADSL broadband technology; if not, why not. (3) Which exchanges within the electoral division of Hasluck are: (a) ADSL broadband enabled, and (b) not ADSL broadband enabled. (4) How close to an ADSL enabled exchange must a customer be located to guarantee them access to ADSL broadband. (5) Are there any other factors which affect ADSL broadband access other than excessive distance to an ADSL enabled exchange. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question, based on advice provided by Telstra: (1) There are 17 exchanges, wholly or partly, within the electoral division of Hasluck and all of these exchanges are ADSL enabled. Therefore all of the suburbs identified in the question have access to ADSL. However, due to the impact of certain access line electronics and distance limit factors, access to ADSL is limited to approximately 86% of people with a telephone service within the Hasluck electorate. (2) (a) As noted in the answer to part (1) above, approximately 14% of people within the Hasluck electorate are unable to access ADSL, due mainly to certain access line electronics and distance limit factors. (b) The access line electronics issue and distance factors mean that ADSL will never reach 100% of premises. Nevertheless, areas of high aggregate demand for broadband within the existing ADSL footprint may be retrofitted at some time in the future where this is considered economically viable. In this context, Telstra is currently developing an online Broadband Demand Register to assist in assessing broadband demand in particular areas. Generally speaking, for customers unable to access ADSL, the current alternatives are: satellite (available everywhere); ISDN (available at virtually all urban exchanges); and cable (which passes approximately one third of living units in Australia) While households in the Hasluck electorate do not have access to cable infrastructure, the other two alternatives are available. (3) There are 17 exchanges, wholly or partly, within the electoral division of Hasluck, of which all are already ADSL enabled. The Huntingdale exchange, adjacent to Hasluck, is planned to be enabled by the end of June 2003. (4) A customer must be located within approximately 3.5 kms from their exchange in order to access ADSL. This approximate distance limit is driven by technical standards, and is determined in each case by the electrical attenuation of the copper telephone line. Each customer’s line is checked for its capability to be provided with ADSL, before Telstra proceed with ADSL service provision. (5) Apart from the exchange not being enabled, the main reasons for customers being unable to access ADSL are: excessive distance from the exchange, and the presence of certain access line electronics. There are also three further conditions that can infrequently occur, and will also prevent ADSL:

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Artsan incompatible product utilising the existing copper line (eg, ISDN); a potentially interfering product utilising an adjacent copper pair in the cable; and special line conditioning equipment on some cables required to improve voice transmission. Taxation: Information Sharing (Question No. 1764) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, upon notice, on 26 March 2003: Do the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Securities and Investment Commission and the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia share information with a view to each body fulfilling its objectives laid out in its business plan; if not, why not. These matters are the responsibility of the Treasurer and the Attorney-General. World Exposition: Japan (Question No. 1768) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 2003: (1) Is the Australian government planning to participate in the World Exposition taking place in Aichi Prefecture, Japan, from 25 March to 25 September 2005; if not, why not. (2) If the Australian government is planning to participate, (a) has an application been submitted; if not, when will it be submitted, (b) what will be the extent of Australia’s participation, (c) what will be the size of the delegation, and (d) what will be the content of the delegation. (3) Will any members of the Government be attending; if so, who. (4) What preparations have been made for the Exposition. (1) The Government will make a decision on whether to participate in the 2005 World Exposition, to be held in Aichi, Japan, as part of the 2003-04 Budget process. (2) See answer to question (1). (3) See answer to question (1). (4) As part of its consideration on whether to participate in the 2005 World Exposition, the Government has prepared some preliminary cost estimates for an Australian pavilion. Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Relocation (Question No. 1770) Mr Danby asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 26 March 2003: (1) Is the Minister aware of the move of the majority of the ABC Television studios in Melbourne from Ripponlea to South Bank. (2) Is the Minister aware of the residents’ concerns about the future of the land at Ripponlea, and that the unclear status has led to fear, insecurity and great speculation. (3) What is the history of the ownership and use of the land. (4) In respect of the decision on the future of the land at Ripponlea: (a)who is responsible for making the decision, (b) when will it be made, (c) what will the process be for making this decision, (d)
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Hockey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows :what factors will be taken into account, and (e) will the public have an opportunity to comment during the process. (5) Can the Minister assure residents that the land will: (a) not become housing estates, and (b) will be returned to the public. (6) Is the Minister aware that the closest public park in the area is over a kilometre away, out of walking distance of most of the elderly and younger residents. (7) Is the Minister aware that a small piece of former Crown land in the area on the corner of Dorgan Street and Kooyong Road was recently returned to the public as a Memorial Park; if so, is the Minister able to say whether that decision is a useful precedent in respect of the land at Ripponlea. (1) No. I have not yet been notified by the ABC about the possible relocation from Rippon Lea. (2) No. There have not been any representations made to me from the community on this matter. (3) The ABC has occupied 2 acres of Rippon Lea since 1956, known as the Gordon Street site, which was acquired by the Commonwealth for the ABC to use for television production. In 1963 the Commonwealth compulsorily acquired a further 4.1 acres north of the studios, but this was given to the National Trust in 1974 for conservation purposes as part of Rippon Lea, following negotiation. The Commonwealth transferred ownership of the Gordon Street site to the ABC in 1991. (4) (a) The ABC. (b) The ABC has advised that there is no timetable confirmed at present. (c) The ABC has advised that the feasibility of the proposal has to be assessed by the ABC and its Board, and would follow a Public Works Committee process. (d) Environment and heritage would be amongst those factors to be considered by the ABC. The ABC may need to consider the possible requirement to refer the relocation from the Gordon Street site to the Australian Heritage Commission for comment under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, as Rippon Lea and its gardens are entered in the Register of the National Estate. The ABC may also need to consider a referral to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. (e) Yes, as part of the Public Works Committee process. (5) (a) and (b) These matters will be addressed through the Public Works Committee process. (6) These matters will be addressed through the Public Works Committee process. (7) These matters will be addressed through the Public Works Committee process. Immigration: Detainees (Question No. 1772) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2003: (1) Under the Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters signed by Australia and Iran on 12 March 2003 what arrangements have been agreed to for the handling of those Iranians currently in detention who do not volunteer to return to Iran. (2) Do the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding or any policies arising from them penalise those Iranians currently in detention who do not agree to return voluntarily to Iran. (3) What measures have Australia and Iran agreed to promote the voluntary repatriation of Iranians currently in detention in Australia. (4) Could he provide a copy of the Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters with the government of Iran to the House; if not, why not.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Under the Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran has agreed to accept the return of all Iranian nationals who have no legal right to remain in Australia, subject to their identity being confirmed. (2) No. (3) The Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters provides for the offer of financial assistance to promote and facilitate the voluntary return to Iran of Iranian nationals who have no legal right to remain in Australia. This reintegration package, which provides for AUD 2,000 per person and up to a maximum of AUD 10,000 per family, is designed to assist individuals and families to re-establish their lives in Iran. Officers of my Department will counsel detainees on the terms of the package. Iranian consular representatives will be available should detainees wish to discuss arrangements for their return to Iran. (4) The Government does not consider it to be in the public interest to make the Memorandum of Understanding on Consular Matters publicly available at this time. The document was signed on the understanding that it is a confidential agreement between governments that would not be released publicly. Human Rights: Violations (Question No. 1786) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2003: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 1148 (Hansard, 12 December 2002, page 10631), is he aware of any allegations of human rights violations and property crime committed by Turkey against Australians of Cypriot origin. (2) Will the Government provide any financial assistance to Australians of Cypriot origin in order for them to commence legal action against Turkey in the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR); if so, what will that assistance be; if not, why not. (3) Will the Government support or sponsor the establishment of an Eminent Persons Group on Cyprus under the auspices of the Commonwealth Heads of Government (CHOGM); if so, is he able to say whom he will recommend for that group; if not, why not. (4) Will the Government condemn Turkey for failing to comply with the ECHR judgement in both Loizidou vs. Turkey and Cyprus vs. Turkey; if so, when; if not, why not. (5) What diplomatic pressure will the Government apply to persuade Turkey to comply with the judgements of the ECHR. (1) I am aware that a number of dual Australian/Cypriot nationals have sought to take action against Turkey in the European Court of Human Rights over the denial of their property rights in northern Cyprus. (2) Financial assistance under the Special Circumstances (Overseas) Scheme (which is the only scheme of possible relevance in this matter) is provided in only the most exceptional cases. Financial assistance may be authorised under that Scheme where there is a “moral obligation” on the part of the Commonwealth to provide assistance, or there are “compassionate grounds” for the Commonwealth to provide assistance. Assistance is usually provided only in relation to those matters where the Commonwealth has a direct involvement in the matter and the liberty of the person involved is at stake. It is unlikely that this necessary element of ‘moral obligation’ or ‘compassionate grounds’ could be derived from private civil proceedings undertaken in a foreign country against a foreign government, on the basis of a foreign citizenship. This is particularly so because the Australian
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Government is, in principle, unconvinced of the merits of funding private legal actions against foreign governments in foreign courts. (3) The Commonwealth has supported the resolution of the situation in Cyprus through encouragement of the multilateral mechanisms of the United Nations and through bilateral channels, rather than a parallel process of mediation. In the absence of any initiative by Cyprus, as the country most concerned, or by the Commonwealth Secretary-General, to establish an ‘eminent persons group’ on Cyprus under the auspices of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM), Australia has not sponsored or supported the establishment of such a group. (4) Australia is not a Party to the European Convention on Human Rights which established the European Court of Human Rights. It would therefore not be appropriate for Australia to comment on Turkey’s compliance with the Court’s judgements in Loizidou vs. Turkey and Cyprus vs. Turkey. (5) Australia is not a Party to the European Convention on Human Rights which established the European Court of Human Rights. It would therefore not be appropriate for Australia to bring influence to bear on Turkey regarding its compliance with the Court’s judgements. Health: Modafinil (Question No. 1787) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 27 March 2003: (1) Further to the Minister’s reply to part (6) of question No. 1170 (Hansard, 5 February 2003, page 11058), what evidence has been received by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) regarding the listing of Modafinil on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). (2) Is the Minister able to say what evidence is required by the PBAC to enable a recommendation for PBS listing of Modafinil to be made; if so, what is the nature of that evidence; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: (1) Applications made by sponsors to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) are commercial-in-confidence. As such, the Department is not in a position to provide these details. (2) An application to the PBAC for listing a medicine on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is required to include evidence relating to the medicine’s clinical effectiveness, safety and costeffectiveness compared with other treatments listed on the PBS. Ministerial Statements: Translations (Question No. 1790) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 March 2003: (1) Does the Government have a policy on the circumstances in which it would be appropriate to translate Prime Ministerial and Ministerial statements into community languages at taxpayers’ expense; if so, what are the details. (2) What were the reasons behind the Government’s decision to translate his parliamentary statement on Iraq into Arabic and Bahasa Indonesian and who initiated such action. (3) Which Government agency arranged for the translations to be made and what was the cost. (4) According to the 2001 Census, what proportion of Australians who speak a language other than English at home were recorded as speaking (a) Arabic and (b) Bahasa Indonesian. (5) On what basis was it decided to translate the speech into these two particular languages and not into other languages.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(1) There is no set policy, but translations of Prime Ministerial and Ministerial statements are undertaken when there are compelling reasons on national and community interest grounds for broader community awareness of the content of such statements. (2) The decision to translate the speech into Arabic reflected the fact that Iraq is an Arabic speaking country and many community groups with an interest in the Iraq issue are Arabic speakers. The translation into Indonesian reflected the fact that Indonesia has the world’s largest Muslim population and is one of Australia’s nearest neighbours. The action to arrange translation was initiated by my office. (3) The Translation was arranged by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet with the assistance of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The cost of translation was approximately $176. (4) (a) Arabic: 209,372 persons (1.1 per cent of the total Australian population) (b) Indonesian: 38,724 persons (0.2 per cent of the total Australian population). (5) As per (2) above. Iraq (Question No. 1795) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2003: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1373 (Hansard, 25 March 2003, page 13246), is it the case that the US government supports the Iraqi National Congress and Kurdish autonomy as part of a federal Iraq; if so, is Australia’s policy on Kurdish autonomy within a federal Iraq different to that of the Coalition of the Willing. (2) Has the Australian government had a less supportive attitude to the Kurds than the British and the Americans; if so, why. (3) Does the Government consider recognition of Kurdish authorities within the boundaries of Iraq to be equivalent to Australia supporting the creation of an independent Kurdish state; if so, why. (4) Is the Australian government seeking to liberate the Iraqis, including the Iraqi Kurds; if so, why has it refused to meet or talk to them since 1993. (5) When will he or his officials enter into discussions about the reconstruction of Iraq with the two Kurdish governments, whose freedom of speech, economic progress and relative freedom, he has been citing in the House. (6) Was the US represented by Mr Ambassador Khalilzad at a meeting of all Iraqi exile groups in Sulaymaniyah in the Kurdish area of Iraq in February 2003. (7) Did the Australian government seek or receive Mr Khalilzad’s report on plans for a future democratic federal Iraq, if so, do these plans include an autonomous Iraqi Kurdistan. (1) It is not usually our practice to comment on the policy approach of other governments. Australia supports the cultural and political aspirations of ethnic groups in Iraq being met within existing territorial boundaries, and peacefully. Australia also supports genuine political representation and non-discriminatory policies for ethnic groups in Iraq. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has referred to possible application of the concept of federalism to post-conflict political arrangements in Iraq but has emphasised that the nature of Iraq’s future government is ultimately a matter for the Iraqi people themselves to determine. (2) No.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Howard
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) The Australian Government does not recognise any of the Kurdish “Parliaments”, “Governments” or “Congresses” – whether located in Iraq or elsewhere and does not accord their representatives any special status. For reasons relating to the territorial integrity of UN member states, Australia does not support the creation of an independent Kurdish state unless it is agreed to by all other states whose territorial integrity would be affected by the creation of such a state. Australia considers the Kurds to be minorities in the countries in which they live and believes that their cultural and political aspirations should be met by working within existing territorial boundaries. The Australian Government stresses the importance of fully respecting international human rights norms in the treatment of Kurdish minorities. (4) The Government’s key objective remains to disarm Iraq of its Weapons of Mass Destruction. Australian Government representatives continue to meet from time to time with Kurdish community leaders in Australia and overseas. (5) See the response to Questions 3 and 4 above. Kurdish representatives attended the meeting held in Tallil, Iraq on 15 April to discuss future political arrangements in Iraq. Australia was represented at this meeting. Kurdish representatives must of course be involved in further discussions about the reconstruction of Iraq and transitional governance arrangements. (6) This is an issue for the US Government. (7) No.
title: Questions On Notice
